editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: As it was Acted at the DUKE'S THEATER.

q.l: â€”Aequanimitas
Poetae ad scribendum augeat industriam.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Simon Neal, at the Three Pigeons in Covent-Garden 1682.

list.label: Timothy Turbulent, One that hates all sorts of Government and Governours, and is always railing against the Times, Guardian to his Neece Mrs. Well-bred.
Furnish, Nephew to Mr. Turbulent, a swaggering, debauched Person, who has nothing, lives by his Wits, yet furnishes others with Money and Goods.
Hangby, A Creature of Furnish's, and a Cheat.
Grin Sneak, A great Projector, and a Fop.
Finical Cringe, A Balderdash Poet, and an Apish Citizen, makes love to Mrs. Well-bred.
Rabsheka Sly, A Creature of Mr. Turbulent's, and one of his private Cabal, a private Sinner, and Railer against the Times.
Abednego Suck-Thumb, Another Creature of Turbulent's, a Melancholly Visioner.
Mr. Fairlove, A Gentleman of Sense and Understanding, in love with Mrs. Lucy.
Friendly, Of his acquaintance, averse to Marriage.
Dr. Quibus, A French Doctor, that gives Physick to Turbulent.
Pollux, Turbulent's Man.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.label: Mrs. Turbulent.â€”
Lady Medler, A very busie, Match-making Lady, and pretender to get Pattents for Sneak.
Lucia Well-bred, Neece to Mr. Turbulent, in Love with Fairlove.
Priscilla, Turbulent's Daughter, A Quaker, yet desirous to be thought Learned.
Mrs. Sly, Wife to Rabsheka.

p.hi: Mad-Men and Women, Constables, Drawers, Fidlersâ€”

sp.l: HOW cruelly do Poets rack their Brains!
For small Applause, and little or no gains;
Courting your sick and squeamish Appetite,
Still with fresh pleasure, and a new delight.
They strive to please you, with no little pain,
And try to humor you in every strain,
From the high Rant, of Thundring, Rhimeing Verse,
To mimic Baudy Droll, and humble Farce.
Lovers from every place, of every Age,
Their Tragic Muse have brought upon the Stage,
Whilst Comick Satyr strove to represent
All sorts of Fools, to give you all content.
Poets have robb'd the Earth, Heav'n, Air and Seas
Of Objects, trying every way to please,
With Songs, with Dances, and with painted Scenes,
With Drums, with Trumpets, and with fine Machines,
They've shewn you Angels, Spirits, Devils too,
Hoping to find some way to pleasure you
With something that was very rare and new:
All this for you have drudging Poets done,
Losing the dear-bought Fame they once had won.
You come not now sharp set, pleas'd with each bit
Of Tragic Sense, and season'd Comic Wit;
But now you come with Stomachs, as if full,
Tast nothing, but cry out, the Poets dull.
Not much unlike to an ill-natur'd Guest,
Who having fill'd his Belly, blames the Feast.
When you'll scarce come to'a noted Poets Treat,
Or when you do, will hardly like the Meat,
Our Poet fears, cloy'd with such various Feasts,
He shan't find any thing to please our Guests:
That nothing with pall'd Appetites will down,
Unless he brings some Fruit you have not known.
Poets have been so lavish and so kind,
New Characters are very hard to find,
And all the Fools, Court, City, Country yield,
Already have been muster'd in this Field:
But he at last did on some Mad-Men light,
With whom he'll entertain you here to Night;
Hoping that his Fanatic Melancollicks
Will make you laugh, at their unusual Frolicks:
What e're the Title in the Bill may say,
He thinks 'twill prove no Melanchollick Play.
SEE Gentlemen, I now am Sober grown,
And all Fanatic Turbulence disown:
I who did Rail, and roar against the Times,
And still was rakeing in the Kingdoms Crimes,
Who meddled with all matters, and made known
All Faults, but never told, nor saw my own,
In silence now, Crimes, Follies, Madness too,
Can see, and laugh, and snear like some of you.
Bethlem's a Blessed Hospital, and fit
T' effect the Cure of each crack'd Brain and Wit,
And may deserve a Song, as well I tro,
As th' Monument, or Weather-cock of Bow:
Thither let all Fanatics of this Age,
Who trouble both the Church, the State and Stage
Be sent; spare dyet, whipping, letting Bloud
Is far more proper, and may do more goods
T' all who run mad in Coffe-house and Ale-house,
Than either Newgate, Pillory or Gallows.
Send thither every Lay and Frantick Widgeon,
Who coble, botch, patch, and translate Religion;
Who leave their Awles, their Needles, Hammers, Shears,
To meddle with, and prate of State Affairs:
Who cry down Vice, yet love a private VVhore,
These, and alas! to name, too many more,
VVant Doctor Quibus Pill of Hellebore.
You Critticks too, who damn our Poets so,
Pray do not think that you shall Scot-Free go;
For all you half-brain'd VVits, who never fail,
Against both Poets, and their Plays to rail,
Who still find fault, tho oft told of it here,
Like our mad Aristotle and Scalliger,
In Bethlem 'mong the rest ought to appear.
I'll say no more, lest I should tedious grow,
But only make one Prayer e're I go.
With this New Play, may you all pleased be
May we all live in peace, and all agree,
And may all Turbulents find Cure like Me.

div.head: SCENE. I. MOORFIELDS. ACT I.
div.stage: Enter Pollux alone, telling some Brass Farthings out of one hand into the other.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: ONE, Two, Three, Four, Five, Six, Seven, Eight, with these Eight Farthings must I purchase Six several sorts of Commodities: Very goodâ€” what a pretty Office I have? 'tis the chief of my work to trot about these Errands all day long, for a covetous, stingy, griping old Devil my Master, who feeds me with Leek Porredg and Cow-Heels, whilst he fills his own Guts with cramb'd Chickens, Turky-Eggs, and white Broaths, till he lays it up againâ€” Odsnigs I have lost one of my Brass Guiniesâ€” kneels as to look his farthing.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Why how now Pol? what art thou poaking for i'the dirt?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O Mr. Fair-love, I am undone, I have lost the Eighth Part of my Purchase-Money, I was going to lay out for my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come give it o're, here, I'll make it up for thee, what hast lost?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay, not much, but a Farthing: it is but eating our Cowheel without Mustard to day.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Here Polâ€” here's a Shilling for thee.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Thank you Sir, if I could but lose money thus every day, and gain by the loss, I should grow rich, like those who lose a Hundred Pound by a Fire, procure a charitable Brief, with one more, and get Six Hundred Pounds by it.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Well Pol, I see you know the World, but prethe let Mrs. Lucy know that I am in this Walk, and would willingly kiss her hand; you know Pollux I dare not be seen in Mr. Turbulent's House, and Mrs. Lucy has desired me to forbear coming thither her self.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I know it Sir, very well: I shall give her notice of your being here instantly; but she is so busy, I believe she cannot steal forth at this time.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Why Pol? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O Sir, My Master has taken Physick to dayâ€” a kind of grumbling came over his Maw, which I doubt was a Surfeit got by eating of Rashers of Bacon and poatch'd Eggs th'other day, with his Nephew Furnish: but Doctor Quibus, the gibberishâ€” sputtering French Doctor, tells him it is Melancholy, and that he must purge it away.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And what is all this to Mrs. Lucy? Methinks now he is ty'd to his Close-stool, she may the better leave the House.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I tell you Sir, the whole Family is employed, and all too little, to wait on him: He is turbulent to purpose, for a little yellow â€¢ sh Powder the Doctor gave him, which he called Enemetic, has so claw'd him off, that there is the Devil and all to do with him. I shall be Hang'd for staying.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: But however, I don't see, but that Mrs. Lucy may get forth for all this.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay, You won't hear me, my Mistress holds his head whilst he discharges; my young Mistress Priscilla holds the Bason to catch the Stream forsooth, and your fair Mistress Lucy warms the Napkins to rub the Sweat off from his Countenance.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: A good employmentâ€” Well Pol, however do you but whisper her that I am here, and leave the rest to her tender discretion.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sir, your Servantâ€” I will not fail to tread on her Toe, and lay my Lips to her Ear immediately. Exit.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Frank Faireloveâ€” What the Devil do you do here? Is it to snuff the Air of Bun-fields? or have you a City Intrigue, to meet some Shop-keepers Wife?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I may as well ask you, what you do here? you belong to the other end of the Town as well as I.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why, it lay in my way, and I was passing the Fields, as a man does a Ford in a River, as suddenly as I can, I long to be out of them, they stink of City-Dog-house. But you I see are taking your serious turns here, as if it were for Recreation or Meditation, or that you took more delight in Moor-Fields than in the Train-swept-Malt, or glorious Hide-Park.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Why, Will. Friendly, do you speak against a place that you know not? you are much mistaken in supposing here is no Recreation.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Yes, here are Recreations indeed, to see the Wenches dry their Cloaths, and the Boys play at Grass-Cat, the Archers in Finsbury to shoot at Rovers, and Nine-pin-Alleys, and Bawdy-houses in every Quarter; what other Recreations canst find?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p:
Yes, all the Varieties thou canst imagine. Oh the several sorts of People that walk in these Fields, the Saint, the Sot, the
Cheat, the Cully, the Grave, the Frollick, the Wise, the Fool, the Melancholy, the Religious, the Fanatic, the Usurers, the Philosophers, the Alchymists, the Quacks, the Shop-keeper, from the Mercer to the Cobler, and Stocking-mender, with all their Wives, Daughters, Neeces and Maidens.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Fairly reckoned, you forgot the Mad-men too, in Bethlem, they make part of the Rarities. But methinks St. James's Park, and the fair Bevie, that is there to be seen every Night, should have more attraction. The bright, fair, bucksom, witty, fine, willing and airy Girles at that end of the Town, should give more delight than green Aprons, and Grogaram Gowns or Petticoats that stink of Soap and Tallow, or the Cypress Chests and Lavender.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Every man as he likes. I know your aim is at some fine, witty, frollic, bucksom Miss, which some unmannerly Puppies call Wenches, and others most abominably asperse by the term of Whore. Why Faith Will. this place is not without those Creatures, and plenty of them too, of all sorts and sizes, though perhaps not so well prinkum prankum'd, or so modishly rigg'd: These are a sort of demure Whores, with little Rings upon their Foreheads, a strait Hood, and a narrow diminitive Colverteen Pinner, that makes them look so Saint-like, that you would swear 'em the Daughters of innocence it self.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This is something to the purpose, I like the place the better for that; but prethe be plain with thy Friend, and do not conceal thy Intrigue: who is it you are in quest of, that has so strong a Cart-Rope, as to draw thee from all the fine things in the Mall, to these stinking Tents of Bottle Ale and rusty Bacon? sure 'tmust be some rare piece: Or art thou cloy'd with Partridge and Pheasant, and long'st after Hung-Beef, musty Swines-flesh, or Rashers on the dirty Coales?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You are still besides the Mark Will. 'tis no ordinary Game that I hunt in these Fields.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why so sly Frank? I never had a Miss or Intrigue yet, but I discovered it to thee; this is unkindly, the very Air of this place spoils your good nature.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I will tell you then, I am damnably, desperately, deeply in Love, and so have bin several Moneths too, and with an honest, witty, beautiful, well-bred, discreet, young Lady, and one that has Money boy to boot.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: To have bin in Love for several Moneths, is no such strange thing, with a witty, beautiful, well-bred, discreet, young Lady; but if she be honest, and you cannot hope to make her otherways, what do you do with her?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I see you follow your old Game Willâ€” But I assure thee, mine is an honourable and lawful, and meer Matrimonial Design.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Heavens forbidâ€” Matrimonial Love say you? thou
art not so intoxicated yet? what Marry, when all the World forsake their Wives, and fall to keeping? when 'tis grown as much out of Fashion as Trunk Breeches; thou hast convers'd fairly with Moor-Fields.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Away, away, let's have no tilting against Marriage, the Theam is grown thred-bare, there is scarce a Comedy without it, the Poets and the Stage have laught at it so long, that they begin to be laught at themselves for it. I tell thee Will. Friendly, mine is a fair, honest, downright, Matrimonial-Love, with a very honest fair, young, witty Gentlewoman, and now, in truth, you have my whole Intrigue.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If it be so, I think thou art turned an honest, down-right, plain-dealing Sot. Dost not thou know that there is not a more unbecoming thing in Nature, than to see a Gentleman handing and waiting on his Wife.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for that, I have therefore withdrawn my self to this end of the Town, even to Moor-Fields, where 'tis no shame to do so; Men and their Wives ordinarily walk here together very lovingly.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ay, Citizens and Shop-keepers, who are wedded to their old Fashions.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I believe it will grow in Fashion again, at the other end of the Town shortly: Misses are so very chargeable, humorsome, proud, impertinent and tyrannical, that no Wife in the World can be more. But I am resolv'd, and am not now to be shaken, therefore forbear.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But may not I see this fine, powerful Charm of yours?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Yes, you may in time, I am not shy, and I think need not be jealous of thee; for thou canst love nothing that's honest.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: That's because I could never meet with that Chimoera, but you it seems, have found this rare Jewel.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Did you know her you would say so in Earnest, she is a Jewel out shewn in the Dark, which makes her Carbuncle-like, to shine the brighter.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If it ben't i'the dark, 'tis such a hole, I should ne'r have sought for a Jewel in.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: That's nothing to the Family she lives in, and to the People she is forc'd to converse with.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, who is she? her Name, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Why I'll tell thee, her name is Lucia, Well-bred, a Gentlemans Daughter, who dying, left her under the Guardianship of one Mr. Timothy Turbulent, whose Wife was Sister to her Father. Now he, with his hypocritical Sanctity, got so far into the Esteem of his Brother-in-Law, that he left his Daughter to his Care, with full power to see her bestowed in Marriage, but her Portion he committed to the safe keeping of the Chamber of London, which is 5000 Pounds.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: He was wise in that.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: This Mr. Turbulent is one that is still Railing against the Times, the Court, the King, the Church, the Government, and almost every thing that stands in his way, loves to speak Treason privately, and has a great delight and faculty that way.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A good Guardian.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: His Wife is one that has walk'd throw all Religions, and at last is come into the Society of the Sweet Singers. His Daughter is an impertinent, and unmannerly Quaker, yet pretends to Knowledge, Learning and Logick.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Fore George, your Jewel's well set.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Besides, The Gang that follows this Mr. Turbulent, and visits his House, of Anabaptists, Vitioneers, Quakers, Hypocrites, Cheats and Fools of all sorts; which are the only People, my Mistress is suffered to converse with.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But in what Predicament stard you with your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: The business of Wooing is past, we are come to a Conclusion; but Mr. Turbulent knowing me to be one of the un-sanctified-end of the Town (as he calls it) has absolutely forbid me all entrance into his Mansion, so that I cannot see Lucy, but by stealth.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thou deservest this Gentlewoman, who e'r she be, for ventring into such a Place and People for her sakeâ€” 'Tis far beyond the Voyage of Orpheus for Euridice, or of Jason for the Golden Fleece, the Furies and the Dragons and wild Bulls, were not so dangerous as these sort of People thou hast named.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You may see by this the power of Love, that I can walk with pleasure under these Trees, the contemplation of Pay-day Melancholy.

div.stage: Enter Cringe singing, drest most exactly with Ribbons and â€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Fa la fal fal la la fa la faâ€”

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Whom have we here? a kind of a Morrice-dancer by his trip and trim.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: O Sir, 'tis my Rival, one that Mr. Turbulent designs for Lucies Husband, he is a Mercer of Lombard-Street, his name is Finical Cringe.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Fa la la fal la laâ€”

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A pretty spruce airy What d'ye lack Sir.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Yes, he learns to sing, dance, fence and to play of the Violin, scorns to be like the Citizens, but scurvily imitates the Courtiers. Nay he is a pretender to Poetry, makes Sonnets and Acrosticks on his Mistress Name. He goes duly to Pinners Hall with Mr. Turbulent, where he writes the Sermons, and when he comes home, privately reads Plays and Romances. To this Ape has Mr. Turbulent promised Mrs. Lucy, for which he is to have 500 l. of â€¢ er Portion for his Daughter Priscilla.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why dost not beat him, but suffer him to co â€¢ rt thy Mrs.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: What, beat an Assâ€” there is no danger of him, he is Lucies only diversion, and serves to make her sport as much as a Monkie. Oh he sees usâ€”

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: Mr Fairelove, honoured Mr. Fairelove, I kiss your hand, humbly kiss your hand hehâ€”hehâ€”
sp.l: This is your friend heh!
I humbly kiss yours hehâ€”
sp.stage: salutes them with many fine Bows and Cringes.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Your servant Sir, whither are you going Mr. Cringe? what to see Mrs. Lucy I warrant.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I am going to make her my daily Visit heh, and to illuminate my self by her lustre heh â€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You are a happy man Mr. Cringeâ€” you are going to offer some Copy of Verses now to her fair hands â€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Who I? fa la fa la laâ€” I can a little at Poetryâ€” but you have so many better Poets at your end of the Town heh, heh, that you dislike us City Wits, hehâ€”

sp.speaker: Frien.
sp.p: Pox on him for a Baboon, what do you discourse with him so long for?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Prethee be quiet, he will shew his Verses now, either stolen out of some Play-Book, or of his own making.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What does the Coxcomb heh so at us?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis his word of Expectation, the Fop thinks it a grace, and has us'd himself so long to't, he cannot speak ten words without it, and it makes up a great part of his Oratoryâ€” see he's a pulling out his Papers, Cringe reads to himself and smiles.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This is Moor-fieldsâ€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come, come Mr. Cringe, let us see your Raptures, you are reading thereâ€” my Friend here is a very good Judg of Verses.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: 'Tis a pretty Conceit heh, a very pretty conceit heh â€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come what is't, let's see it.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Why 'tis a Copy of Verses of a Pin that fell from Mrs. Lucies Sleeve, and I put it upon mine hehâ€” carried it home heh, and this Morning I made these Verses heh, which I am going to present her, with her Pin again heh; is it not a pretty Conceit heh?â€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Yes, and shews much Wit, the Great Virgil did not disdain to write on a Gnat, and a Fly, and a Flea; yea a Louse, has been the Theam of the Witty Poets, among which we will place your Pin.

sp.speaker: Cring.
sp.p: The Conceit is new I assure you, heh â€” here Mr. Fairelove, you shall read 'em â€” heh!

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: No, by no means, you will grace 'em best your self â€” your Poets always love to read their own Verses, they know where to give the Emphasis, and how to accent them, with the true rise and fall of the Voiceâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Well thenâ€”

div.stage: Upon a Pin dropt from Mrs. Lucies fair Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Had it not been betterâ€” upon fair Mrs. Lucies Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: No, that is not so newâ€” Mark the Conceit heh.

Readsâ€”
Return sweet Pin, unto my sowr sweet foe,
Tell how her secret Charms do play their part,
How like the dart of Cupid, thou dost show,
Which from her eyes, shot through my loving heart!
A wondrous thing! thy touch was harmless to me,
And where thou touch'd me not, thou didst undo me.
How do you like it heh?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Readsâ€”
Yet tell, dear Pin, that thy Enchanted Touch
Did sweeten so the Sleeve, where it was cast,
That there was nothing grieved me so much,
As the remembrance of my Freedom past,
For who may be her Captive, and be free,
A Gally Slave, lives happier than he. what say you hey â€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Very goodâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Readsâ€”
So be thou gone, and yet go not I pray,
Go not, sweet Pin, O go not back at all,
But prick my heart so hard, that Night and Day,
In Death and Life, it be her Beauties Thrall;
And yet, even go, for Duty so commands,
Go gentle Pin again, to her fair hands. Mark that heh, and then I present the Pin heh, a merry Conceit, heh, a Morning Meditation, hehâ€” fal la la la fal fa layâ€” but your friend does not tell me how he likes it heh.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Very scurvily hehâ€” why this Fool is madder than any in Bedlamâ€” prethe let me kick him goingâ€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: By no meansâ€” did you make these Verses Mr. Cringe?

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: Yes Sirâ€” and off hand, this Morning, I did not study much for 'em.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I dare swear he did not.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: But I doubt you stole 'em Mr. Cringe, for I remember I saw the very same Verses, with little alteration on a Scarf, Printed among Collection of rare Poems.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Asideâ€” Who'd think he should have seen that Bookâ€” I thought it had been out of Print, I do but as the greatest Wits do, steal one from another, but I had as good have made 'em, sorit lost as much Labour and Oyl, as the Poets say, to turn a Scarf into a Pin hehâ€”

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I am sure you have turn'd your self into a Wood-Coc.â€” Here's a Moorfield Poet and City Wit, wi h all my heartâ€” 'ilid. Fairlove, art bewitch'd, to hold any l â€¢ nger converse with this Fool, and finical hehing Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: C inge.
sp.p: Mr. Fairlove, your Servant, heh. I see your friend is vapory and huffy hehâ€” your servant, your servant, fa la la fa la laâ€” Exit.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Why are you so angry Willâ€” would you have converse with none but Philosophersâ€” or would you have the man have more Wit than God has given him?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, Natural folly does not offend me, a Jack Adams, a Clown, a Jobbernole; but these fools, that take pains, and are industrious, and laborious to shew their follies, ever make me angry, I can't laugh at 'em.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: But I canâ€” prethee let's withdrawâ€” I see more Company, that will be worse offensive to me, for I hate Knaves, and there are a couple of sufficient ones.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prethe, who are they?â€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come this way, I'll tell theeâ€” going off.

That is one Furnish, a Sisters Son of Mr. Turbulent, a very Cheat, has nothing, yet furnishes all the needy Lords of the Town with money, keeps his Coach, his House well furnish'd, spends high, keeps his Whores, his Footmen, French-Man, &c. and all by his Wits.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I like such a man very well, Knaves are no offence to me, they are very necessary Common Wealth-men, and are as good as a Cat in a House, to pray upon the Vermin Fools. Would there were more of them; but who's thereâ€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: 'Tis one Hangby, a creature of his, and a Conspirator in his Cheatsâ€” they come this way, let's sheere off into the next Walk. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: A Pox of ill luck, my Uncle Turbulent has taken Physick to day, and I cannot have the opportunity of getting him forth. I can do no good with him, whilst the old Hag my Aunt is with him. Nothing will open his heart, but good Sack and Sugar, or sweet Metheglin, or else a Brace of Steaming Capons, with all the accoutrements.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Nay, he is a Devil at Eating, he lays in like Wood a Kent, when he eats on Free Cost.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: He had better eat at a ten Shilling Ordinary, every time he eats with me, I have the right way to coaks him. I know his humour Jackâ€” But I'm at a Devilish Plunge for this 50 l. to stop the Execution that is coming out against my Goods; my Coach and Horses are in jeopardy.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Is it possible you can want money already? it is not many days since I saw thee as rich as a Banker, and rolling in Guinies.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Faith they're all goneâ€” slown boyâ€” they never stay long with me â€” Dost not see what shoales I have following me, that I am fain to forsake my Lodging, or get out on't by 5 in the morning, to avoid them, yet wonder that these sums should be so soon gone.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: You say true.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Besides there is Sir William Needy, Mr Litttlewit, Mr. Pennyless, Mr. Marland, and 40 more that I have furnished, and must furnish as fast as I can. But Puppiesâ€”Puppies Jack begin to grow thin; if I could but meet with them as often as I could desire, I should do well enough.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: But well as to this 50 l. 'tis a small Sum; I never knew thee so gravell'd before for such a little Modicumâ€”what no Trust in the Cityâ€” what! has the Lace-man smelt thee? never a Claret-Merchant! Will the Sadler trust no more Sadles to furnish the Troops going to Flanders, ne're a Draperâ€”Where are your Setters and Ferriters for security; are there no Tradesmen now ready to break, whose Credit is good enough to be bound for a 100 l, or so, and go ships. Where is your honest Rogue Scrivener to draw in hah? Furnish is all this while musing.
What man! a la mort?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: This Uncle of mine vexes meâ€”He begins to hearken to the Old Beldame his Wife, who has lost all her Teeth with scolding; and her Lips are worn so thin that they will not keep her Nose and her Chin from meeting.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: I tell thee Jack I have not sufficiently squeez'd this Uncle of mineâ€”He milks hard now, and I take the more pleasure in it. Oh! the delight I take of putting the Dice upon a wary Fop. If he be covetous let me alone to deal with him. 'Twas no less than 30 in the hundred advantage, with good security, that made this precise Ass my Uncle part with his 500 l. for so much I have had, which he is never like to see again, and this 50 l. to Boot.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: But how?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Let me aloneâ€”Go you away, presently disrobe your self; off with your Cloaths, your Sword, Wig, and Hatâ€”Put your self nimbly into a black Sute of Grogran, below the Knees, a broad skirted Doublet, and Girdle about the middle, and a short black Cloak squirted down before with black Taffity, a broad brim'd Hat, with a great twisted Hatband with a Rose at the end of itâ€”Your Hair is slink enough, and of the precise Cut without your Perriwig: good Jack be nimble, and meet me at the Popes Head Tavern, near to my Uncles, about 3 a Clock in the Afternoon. I will prepare him for you.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I have a Broker in Long-Lane that soon will Attire me in any Garb. I have served you I'm sure in all Habits, from the Lord to that Clown, nay to the Skip-kennelâ€”But what must I do?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Prethee be not impertinent, I think thou art grown dull. Observe your Cueâ€”You are to be a Suter to my Cousin Priscilla.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Enoughâ€”enoughâ€”I have you i' my Noddleâ€”fear me notâ€”Ile be with you without fail. Exit.

sp.speaker: Farn.
sp.p: And I must in the mean time try my skill to get my Uncle to the Tavern, now he has taken Phisick, from that Female Devil my Aunt, whom I dread more than the sight of a Basilisk.
How now Mr. Sneak â€” Prethee wha'ts become of the Captain your great Companion, that was to go on the expedition to conquer the Island of Formosa.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: He had not patience till my Lady Medler could get the Commission, and so he is gone to sell Ale at Wapping.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Gad the better Employment byhalf, and more to be got by it.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: You are always an Infidel Mr. Furnish, but I am come to ask seriously your advice, whether I should accept an Employ that is now offered me, or no?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Accept? what the Devil else should you do but accept? Thou hast not had six pence in thy Pocket this six Moneths to my knowledg but what I have furnished thee with, to go to the Coffie-Houses to meet your damned cheating Roguish Projectors. If thou gets no more by pimping than thou doest by projecting, we shall see through this slender Body of thine shortly. But what in the Name of Wonder, is this Place or Employ that is offered you?

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: I am offered two Places to go Governour of Poetan, or Consul of Marsiellesâ€”which shall I take?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Poetan, where is that?

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: It is a great Kingdom in the West Indies, for which I am to raise 10000 l and I to go Governour.
'Tis a great way off Mr. Sneak, I should rather be Consul of Marsielles.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: I am of your mind, my Lady Medler has as good as got me the Patentâ€”Faith Il'e send thee good store of Muscat.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Consul of Marsielles, hah hah hahâ€”a goodly Consulâ€” But hark you Mr. Consul Sneak, what will then become of all your Projects if you go? will you leave all your Concerns in your Black Box that is worth so many thousand Pounds?

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: Why these Considerations I confess made me make a scruple of itâ€”and now I think better of it, I will not go.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Why where is the Widdow Mr. Consul, that you were in in quest of that was worth a 100000 pound.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: Fye, fye, don't mention her; when I enquired into the Business I found she had but 20000 pound. She took Tobacco, and drunk Brandy, and was no Gentlewoman, and therefore I refused her.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p:
Thou art a damnable lying Rogue â€” I know thou wouldst take up with an Apple-woman that had but 50 l. Hang it Mr. Sneak, you have brag'd so long of your Land in Cornwall that no Body will believe thee. And hast been fool'd so much by every projecting
Codshead, that the whole world laugh at thee, and say thou art onely fit for a Chamber among the Fellows of that great Colledg yonder. pointing to Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: You may say your pleasure Mr. Furnish.â€”I'le leave youâ€”But I question not yet to ride in my Coach and six Horsesâ€”

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Stayâ€”stay, don't go awayâ€”here take sixpence to spend at the Coffee-House, for I'm sure thou hast no money. [takes it.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: Well well, I will pay you again with Interest.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Be ruled by me Mr. Grin, leave your projecting Trade, and keep close to your pimping Trade, 'twill bring you in more money byhalf: Thou art a most excellent Pimpâ€”the Ladies are taken with thy Address.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: Well well, Mr. Furnishâ€”you are full of your jeersâ€” but I am stayd forâ€”

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Be not out of the way in the Afternoon, if need be to be bound with me to my Uncle, Mr. O-yes good security.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: No noâ€”I'm sure I'm bound for some hundreds already for himâ€”But if one of my Projects hits I shall pay all. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Goe thy way for a melancholly, projecting Dreamer, with thy Estate in the Cloudsâ€”Now is he gone sneaking to my Uncle Turbulentsâ€”I wonder what he does there?â€”But who comes sayling hereâ€”Oh my Lady Medler: Now for a Dun, and a Rallieâ€”

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Out upon these paultry Fields; a Person of Quality cannot come to the Doors with a Coach, but must alight and foot it. I would not be seen thus afoot and alone for any thingâ€” uds so, here is Furnish.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Madam your Servantâ€”what going to my Uncle Turbulents?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: O you are a fine Man never to come at me, are not you?â€” I have been at least ten times at the Door in my Coach, but you're never withinâ€” when your turn's serv'd you care not.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: And I think I serv'd her turn too, if I am not mistaken. (aside.) O Madam, I'm sorry for your mishap, t'other night, going home from my House.

sp.speaker: Lad. Med.
sp.p: Your Men had made my Coach-man drunk

sp.speaker: (Furn.
sp.p: And I think I made her more drunk.)

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: That he could not guide his Coach right, but overthrew it and broke all my Glasses. I'm sure it cost me Ten Pounds to put my Coach to rights againâ€” You're a fine Man to keep me till three a Clock i'th' morning, wasn't you?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: (Pox on her I could not be rid on her as long as I had one Bottle of Frontineack left) I did not think it so late, Madam, but what said Sir Edwardâ€” was he not angry?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Angry? would I could see that: an he should be angry with me, I'd make my Lord, my Brother angry with himâ€” angry kether? No I call'd him Sweetface a thousand times, and told him I had been at my Cousens, the Grocer's Wives Labour.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: And he believ'd you?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Why, you don't take him to be so unnatural a Beast as not to believe his own Wife. But where's my Necklace of Pearl I lent you to take up some Money on, did not you promise I should have it within 2 days?â€”

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: A Pox of her Memory, I was afraid of this Dunâ€” Madam, I am about to receive 600 l. this Evening, and then I intend to return it back to your Ladyship, with a pair of silk Stockings for the use of it.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Ay, you are the best Man at Promises in the World, and the worst at Performancesâ€” Indeed Mr. Furnish, I must have it, Sweet-Face has asked me several times why I don't wear itâ€” I'll stay this Moneth for the 50 l. I lent you.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: (And so you're like this 12 Moneths for me; if she has not the Conscience to pay me for what I do for her, I will have the Conscience this way to pay my self.)
Indeed Madam, I will repay you all shortly, and furnish your Ladyship with what Moneys you shall wantâ€”
(I must put her besides this Discourse.
Madam, I wonder you can spare so much time as to come to this End of the Town, considering the many Affairs you have in hand, of benefit and weighsâ€” My Lord your Brother helps you to many a Pound.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Tho I say itâ€” I have more to do than my Lord Chancellorâ€” and my Lord my Brother has many grand intrigues in hand, I assure you; but 'tis a great secret, he is now making an Union between the Muscovite and the Turk, and by his means there will be shortly a League, Offensive and Defensive, between the Grand Seignior and the Sophy of Persia; and you will see by next Summer, for all the Peace at Nimiguen, all the States in Christendom Confederated against the French Kingâ€” My Lord Politick knows how to play his Cards.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: You are happy, Madam, in being like himâ€” for though you don't make Matches between Kingdoms and States, yet you make many other very considerable.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I have made some in my timeâ€” and to tell you the truth, I was now going to Mr. Turbulent to propose a Match between a Kinsman of my Lords and his Daughter Pris.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: (Dam herâ€” she'll spoil all my Design) By no means Madam â€” don't do it.

sp.speaker: Le. Med.
sp.p:
Why so Mr. Furnishâ€” I think it is no disparagement to be Related to my Lord my Brother. I tell you Mr. Furnish,
there is not a Woman in all the Kingdom but would be glad and proud of the Honour.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: No question, Madamâ€” But I have already propos'd a Match for my Cousen Priscilla, and you will spoil all.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Nay if it be so, I'm glad I spoke of itâ€” I shall forbear for your sake.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: But Madam, There is one Match that I know of, which if you could bring about would advantage you at least 10000 l.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Bring it aboutâ€” I'll warrant youâ€” ne'r fear man, as long as I have my Lord my Brother to back meâ€”prethe who are the persons?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: 'Tis a difficult business, and I'm loth to tell you.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I will knowâ€” You shall have a share Furnishâ€” Making of Matches is a good Trade, if it be well handled to get Money on both sides; but I must know who these persons be.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Why it is between Antichrist and the Whore of Babylonâ€” 'twould do well if you could bring them together.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Wellâ€” well â€” you jeer me do you? Farewelâ€” but be sure you remember my Necklace.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p:
I shan't forget it Madamâ€” but not a word of my Cousen Priscillas Matchâ€” I'll not leave you, Madamâ€” I'll see you at my Uncle Turbulents.
Exeu â€¢ t.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Fairlove and Mrs. Wellbred.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Your friend yonder is a man of sence; I like himâ€” but I converse with so wretched a Generation, that I am like one coming out of a dark place, dazled with the light of Sence and Reason.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: He is a plain, downright Gentleman that loves to speak his mindâ€”and I'm afraid he'll beat that Fop Cringe, if we leave them too long togetherâ€” Therefore my dear Lucy, answer me to the Question I ask'd you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You may be sure Franc, that I would be glad to be out of this Hell I live in, and dare venture my self with youâ€” and put my Neck in the Yoke of Matrimony â€” but I tell you, I will also bring you the little Fortune my Father has left me, and not give the advantage to my Uncle Turbulent, to cheat me of itâ€” he has a Fanatical Conscience.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I thought I had taken off that Objection, by telling you the good Fortune that has befallen me of 500 l. a Yeer, by the Death of my Uncle in Norfolk. So that now you cannot object (as you use to do) the want of means to live.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You have indeed Franc been very honest in not urging me to Marry before you knew how to keep me like a Gentlewoman, and as many do, to satisfie their pleasure, run themselves headlong into Miseryâ€” But yet I assure you, I will have my Portion before I Marry; tho you are so willing to part with it, I am not.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: But you know how averse he is to me, and that he designs you for that Fop C â€¢ inge, and what power your Father left with him, so that you cannot have your Portion unless you Marry as he would have you. Will you therefore ever live in the Purgatory you are in, and permit me still to languish for want of your company, or else to continue my Walks here among Usurers, Dawds and Punks, to get now and then a sight of you?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No, no, fear it not, I have studied the point, the clause of the Will is this, That if my said Æ²ncle Turbulent be alive, and compos mentis, that he should have the sole dispose of me, and that if I married without his consent, the Chamber of London should not part with my Portion, but it should be at my said Æ²ncles dispose â€” Now if my said Uncle be either dead, or not compos mentis, that clause is null, and the Portion, as I take it, is at my own dispose.

sp.speaker: Fair
sp.p: â€”You are a cunning Lawyer but your Uncle is aliveâ€” as for the other, compos mentis, that I think he is notâ€” but 'tis not what we think, but what the Law will think in that case.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, let me aloneâ€” I will give you leave to get a Licence against to morrow morning, for I have brought my Affairs to such a pass, that by that time the Law shall free me, and he shall be either not alive, or not compos mentis.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I confess I am gravel'dâ€” but I will not question your ingenuityâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But what shall I do with poor Cringe?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Hang him Fopâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I must provide him a Wifeâ€” my Cousen Priscilla, as precise as she is, is taken with that Fool, and extreamly loves himâ€” I must try to get him to Marry herâ€” He is so easie a Fool that I think I shall perswade him to it for all his pretensions to me.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: That would do well â€” see he is run away from Friendlyâ€” I knew he could not endure him long â€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Your most humble Servant heyâ€”your Servant Mr. Fairloveâ€” Fore Gad your Friend yonder is the roughest man I e're talked with heyâ€”I never saw such a surly man in my life heyâ€”he does not love talking he saysâ€”heyâ€”and then I would have read him some Verses heyâ€”and he then grew worse mad heyâ€”and would have tore 'em heyâ€”then I sung fa la la la fal la la la, and gad he was ready to kick me hey, he is fit to converse with no Body but himself hey, and so I left him heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Ay Mr. Cringe, he has his Fitsâ€”you must not take it ill.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I a'nt such an Ass heyâ€”but I'le ne're be alone with him again heyâ€”Come Madam Lucy will you go home heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Nay I shall be angry to if you perswade the Lady to leave my Company so soon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come Mr. Cringe, let's see those Verses you would have shewn Mr. Friendlyâ€”I know they are some I ha'nt seen yet, and I thank you for those of my Pin.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: They are not finished, yet hey I have onely begun a few hey, which I intend to present you when they are finished hey.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No no, I'le see em now while I'm in the humor, or not at all.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You must never deny a Lady any thing.â€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Look here, they are butâ€” fore gad they are not yet finished. about to read
Godslid here's the Gentleman does not love Verses, I dare not read 'emâ€” going to put up the Paper.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come come you shall read emâ€”

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I wonder you can fool thus with this City-maggot; Prethee Frank if thou hast any thing to say to the Lady I'le stay and beat him goingâ€”if not let's goe:

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Prethee Friendly be not so hastyâ€”Mrs. Lucy has a mind to see his Versesâ€”

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: That any one should take such content in the diversion of Fools.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Well I'le read if Mr. Friendly will be but freindly hey I think I was witty there heyâ€”You must know Madam these Verses are not finishedâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why you told us so already, Mr. Cringe, let's hear 'em howeverâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Hem! hem! they are to be directed to you Madam For the fair hands of the more fair Madam Lucia.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I could never tell before which were the fairest, my hands or my face. Proceedâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Hem! hem! readsâ€”
For mighty joys expression in more state
My thoughts Orations did premeditate;
But formal Speeches whistling like th â€¢ Wind,
Ostentate Wit, not Loyalty of Mind:
Sincerity makes little noise, and flies
From hollow hearted, gay Formalities.
How do you like it heyâ€”for gad 'tis excellent, â€¢ o ordinary strains heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: You are no ordinary Puppy I am sure of it.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Your Servant Sir Heyâ€” Hem hem â€”ready.
But your Aversion now I plainly find
Through the Transparent Windows of the Mind;
So a Pellucent Ladies Ivory Skin,
For all her Tiffanies, is seen within. Do you mark that heyâ€”'tis good heyâ€”hem! hem!â€”reads
Your honey Speech was sweet as Woodbine Flower
Of Sugar Lips, too soon was shut the Door.
Soft as the Wooll of Beaver was your stile,
Which makes my ravish'd Sense of Hearing smile;
Your stroking fingers with May-Morning Dew,
My wearied Bodies vigour did renew.
But with delight my Sense of Seeing spies
More amiable Marvels in your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: â€” Snatches the Paper and tears it. I can hold no longer, he has wore out my patienceâ€” why there's more sense in the chattering of a Monkey.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: He has tore the best Copy of Verses that ever was wrote hey, and that's a bold word heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And so it was Mr. Cringe,â€”But is this all pure City Wit- London Witâ€” or Moorfields Meditation.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: No, in good Faith 'tis pure York-shire Wit; for he has took all this out of the York-shire Play called, The Inamouring Girdle.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Godsuckersâ€” I think the Devil is in 'em for finding me outâ€” I must out-face it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Let him take it from whence he will, 'tis like himself, all Nonsence.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: 'Tis all my own Writing, I protestâ€” one thing may be like another hey â€”

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, well Cringe, as long as I like it, all is well; I know no body but your self could write such high strains.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: O Madam, I am your most humble Servant and Admirer heyâ€” but the Gentleman is a very angry Man hey.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Suck-Thumb, habited odly, with his Hat over his Eyes, and walks over the Stage, and goes out.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What kind of Dumb-sad is that?â€” he walks as if he trod on Eggs.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh, he is one of the Gang, resorts much to my Uncle Turbul â€¢ nts, speaks hardly 6 words in 6 hours, and then he gapes like Frier Bacon's Brazen Head. He dreams all day, and sees Visions at night â€” and then relates them for the comfort of the Brethren in Tribulation. All he speaks they take for Oracles. He's one of their private Conventicle or Cabal, where they may speak their minds freely.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A Melancholy Visionere.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Whose Head travels the Moon, and has lodg'd in all the Inns of the Zodiack and the 7 Stars. He has been beyond the eight Sphere, and brings Embassies from thence, his Name is Mr. Abednego Suck-Thumb.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Mr. Turbulent will-think I'm run away with you, Madam Lucy, heyâ€” shall we repair to your Habitation hey?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen, your Servantâ€” Mr. Fairlove let me see you again anon. Whispers.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Your Servant Gent.â€” your with many ridiculous Cringes and Bows. Servant, your humble Servant Mr. Fairlove.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Your Servant Mr. Cringeâ€”

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Your Servant Coxcombâ€” Exeunt Cringe and Lucy. I admire how so well-bred and witty a Gentle-Woman can endure to converse with those kind of Animals that are about her. I like your Choice Frank, but I don't like your Matrimony, is there no other wayâ€” can't you save her from drowning, without sinking your self?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Leave off, I am resolvedâ€” I will deliver her to morrow â€” To morrow Will. thou shalt be at our Wedding.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thou art a kind Servantâ€” Thou'lt deliver her out of Hell, and put thy self into Purgatory. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: THE SCENE. Mr. Turbulent's House. ACT II.
div.stage: Enter Mr. Turbulent, Mrs. Turbulent, Priscilla with a Pipkin of Grewel. Mr. Turbulent in a Night Gown, Caps on his head, a great night-rail flung over his Shoulders â€” &c.

sp.speaker: Turb.
sp.p: WELL here's some Air in this Roomâ€” oh! oh! oh! it was a Thundring Emetticâ€” Lord how it work'd, I am wondrous empty.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Here is a whole Pipkin of Plum Grewel for theeâ€” shall I give thee some of itâ€”

sp.speaker: Turb.
sp.p: Noâ€” I bid you get me some Egg-Caudleâ€” I will have that first, and then the Grewel â€” Egg-Caudle is comfortableâ€” oh! oh! I am very sickâ€” Kate I am very sick, it gripes me yetâ€” It has claw'd me off â€” it has made me very empty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, Mr. Turbulent, and it had been worse; you must be taking Physick of such leud French Doctorsâ€” This was one of your Nephew Furnish's helping to, that sink of Sin, and Son of Perdition, who never did you any good, nor never will â€” Could not Doctor Plussi-Coat here at the next Door, have serv'd your turn, or Doctor Dodipal one of the Brethren?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Hold your peaceâ€” speak not against the Doctor, the Physick has wrought wellâ€” yea very well, both upwards and downwardsâ€” why where's this Caudle?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Why Paul, Paul, why Paulâ€”

div.stage: Enter Pollux with a Mess of Caudle.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Here, I'm coming as fast as I can: I cannot be here and there and every where. I'm sure I serve for all Employs, your Gives Mr. Tur. the Caudle, who falls to eating. foot-boy to run of Errands; your Butler to draw your Beer; your Cook to dress your Meat, and yet I can't please youâ€” Sir shall I get ready the Turky Eggs?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Ay, get them ready against I have eat the Grewel, for I am wondrous empty â€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Will you have all six?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: All six Sirrah?â€” are six so much that your Rascality asks so vain a Question?â€” quickly all sixâ€”I am very emptyâ€” Kate let a Chicken, otherwise called a large Pullet, be got ready for my Supperâ€” and some more Caudleâ€” I find Caudle is good.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: He is become Ravenous; this Physick has but only whetted his craving Stomachâ€” Oh these Cholerick, Turbulent Men are always great eatersâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Sirrah are not you gone yet about the Eggs?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I'm goingâ€” He'll devour me if I stay. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis good Caudleâ€” I find it comfortable Kate.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Vat is dat you eate dere?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Nothing but Egg Caudle Doctor.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Morbleuâ€” Egg Caudle said youâ€” you be de strange man in de hole Varldâ€” The Debil give you de Physic for meâ€” I give de Physic to purge de Color and de Melancolly, and you eate de Caudle to make more Color and Melancoly. For vat is dat do you know?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Don't be angry Doctor, I am emptyâ€” the Caudle is comfortableâ€”

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: De Caudle is poyson, and breeds de color ande de me-lan-col-ly, and it vil come to de fourth degree, and den you vil be madâ€” dat you will get by de Caudleâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You sha'nt perswade me out of my Caudle for all that, 'tis comfortable, yea, I find it very comfortable.

sp.speaker: Quib.
sp.p: Me been two, tree, fore day studying and turning over all de Autors to find cure for your distemper. Me read Galen, Hippocrates, Sennertus Fuchsius and twenty more, and break me Brane vit de study, and now you spoil all vit de Caudleâ€”cramâ€”cramâ€”cramâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Pray what it his Distemper?

sp.speaker: Quib.
sp.p: His distemper is de choloricâ€”Melancolly.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: How dost thou prove that?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You must be prating too â€” what's that to you how he proves it, does Mr. Goose-quil prove all he says?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Yes, he says nothing but what he Proves, and so ought heâ€” He ought to make it plain to the Hearersâ€” we do not understand what he means by cholleric Melanchollyâ€”

sp.speaker: Quib.
sp.p: Maistress Priscilla, you be de very learned Vomanâ€”but you be troubled also very much vid de Melancholly, I can prove datâ€” and all de House is troubled vid de Melancholly, and all de Varld is troubled vid de melancholly.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Thou shouldst tell us howâ€”Thou sayst so, but that is not enough.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Kate, get me some Grewel while the Doctor disputesâ€” I say get me some Grewelâ€”

sp.speaker: Quib.
sp.p: If Maister Turbulent vil give me de leave I will tel de how all de Varld is troubled vit de Melancolly.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Ay Doctor with all my heartâ€” I may then eat my Grewel in quietâ€” I can eat and hearken to the Doctor â€” Kateâ€”the Grewel.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Mark ye me de Melancolly is de general disease of de hole Varldâ€” all de Varld is troubled vit de Melancolly more or less. Democritus did study de Anatomy of de Melancolly, and one Burton your Country-man did write de great Vollome of de Melancolly; but I vil tell you all de hole Book in fower vards. Dere is de Melancollyâ€” fa la â€” de Melancolly pick-strawâ€” de Melancolly Dumb-sad â€” and de Melancolly starkmadâ€” and dere be all de Melancollicks be Gar â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Very well Doctor, proceedâ€”

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Mark ye meâ€” Dere be de fower sorts of de Humors wich cause de fower sorts of de Melancollies, dat is de sanguine or de blood, de Phlegm, de co-lor, and de pure Melancolly or addust blood. Mark ye me, dere be also, one, two, tree, fower degrees of de Melancolly â€” De first is called de Melancolly only, but if it be not purged away, it vil rise to de second degree, and den it is called folly; so to the tird degree vich is extream folly, and lastly, to de fowert degree, vich is madness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Methinks the Doctor speaks very Learnedly.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Go on Doctor go onâ€”

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Vil you never don de eatingâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I eat leisurelyâ€” I hearken Doctor â€” I hear youâ€”

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Vel den, Me vil tel ye how de Melancolly disturbs al Men in de Varld, and is de general distemper of de hole Varld. Mark ye me â€” de seat of de Melancolly is de spleen vich draws to it de ticker and de grosser part of de blood, and ven dat intral is full of de adust Melancolly blood, and does no vel and rightly discharge it self, it mixes it self vit de other humors in de body, and so diffuseth it self torow de hole bodyâ€”Mark ye me. Eating still.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I do Doctorâ€” I doâ€”

sp.speaker: Quib.
sp.p: Den if de Melancolly mixes it self vit de sanguine humor, or de blood, it causes de Melancolly fa laâ€” it makes de laugh, de singing, de caper-ing, de pance-ingâ€”de loveâ€” de brisk-ness â€” de Poetryâ€” de Verses, de Love-Letters, de folly, de mimic gestures, de apishnessâ€” de buffoon and Apish Assesâ€” for de spleen is de seat of de laugh, as well as of de sad and melancolly, but being mixed vit de blood it tickles de spleen, and causes de laugh hah hah hahâ€” de Frenches my Countrymen are very subject to dis sort of de Melancolly, who are alvais laughing and meery, airy, light, and full of de loveâ€”now as dis Melancolly rises in degrees, it expresses it self more or less, an example of vich Melancolly, you have daily in Mr. Cringe, who comes daily to your house, he is, me assure you, much troubled vith dis sort of Melancolly in de tird degree, and if he do not take my Pill for de Melancolly, he vil come to de fowert degree, and den he must go to de great Hospital, and have a chamber dere to be cured.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Very well Doctor, let us hear the other three Doctor, by that time I shall eat up my Grewelâ€”

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Vel den, if de Melancolly mixes vit de Phlegm it causes de Melancolly pick-straw. All de People of de London are very much troubled vit
dis dull and heavy melancholy; dey sit in their shops, and tink, tink, tink, all day long, from morning to de night of notingâ€”all not worth one straw of de little sheat of dere shop, or of de news, buzâ€” buzâ€”buzâ€”dey noting but pick straws all deir life-timeâ€” dis causes de grave and de full folly de starv'd Assâ€”the Politician â€”the Counsello de Projector, de windmils in de head, de formal busie body about notingâ€”it makes the false hopes and de dull foolsâ€”an example of dis melancholly you have in the projecting called Mr. Sneak, who comes often to your house; he is troubled vith dis melancolly pic straw, in de tird degree, and very near de forth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: This Doctor I say is very learned, I begin to be of his Opinion.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Ay Mother, if he could prove it, but I have not yet heard one Sylogism.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Peaceâ€”Doctor proceed â€”as I do eats

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Vel den de tird sort of melancholly, is ven de melancholly mixes vith de serum of the bloud, and makes it stick like puddle water; dis is de pure melancholly, de true atra Bilis black bile, and dis causes de dum sad â€” he sits all day vith his hat dusâ€”and his arms across dusâ€”he no speak vards, he tinks altogether, he imagines strange dings, he sees strange sights, he tinks of de Dible, of his Cloven-foot, and de horns on his head, he tinks of de Moon, and of de Religionâ€”he sees Visions of de Angels, and de strange Beasts, and de Monsters; dis causeth de Prophesie, de Fanatick, de Sects, and de Schisms, and de Hereticks, de Divisions, de dark mists in de fancy, and in de imagination, and de strange Chimeras, and all de strange delusions in de varld. An example of dis is the Visioneer, who often comes hither, one Mr. Abednego Suctum, he is troubled with dis in the fort degree, and is fit for de Bethlem.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I like not that he should accuse Brother Suck-Tum

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Maistres Priscilla is troubled vith dis melancholly in de tird degree, mixed vith de phlegm melancholly, but she may yet be cured; but I tink Mr. Suctum is past cure; and all de Elebore in d' Antycyra vil not give him de perfect cure.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Well, Doctor, let us here the fourth.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
De fort and de last melancholly, is ven it mixes vith de Color; and dis causes de melancholly stark madâ€”dis is de slava Bilis de yellow bile, or de colorick melancholly dat causes all de quarrels in de vorld, and makes de fiting, de Riots, de Routs, de peevishness, de angriness, de beating one another, de disputing, de Railings, de Revilings, de Treasons, and de Treasonable Speeches, de Turbulences, de Rebellions, and opposition of de Governours, and de Government, of de Kings and his Laws, and of all unquietness in de vorld; Dis is de melancholly Mr. Turbulent which disturbs you, and which you have in de tird degree, and entring upon the so â€¢â€¢ , and for which you took my Emmetic to purge it out, and to cure you, and â€¢ ow you goe spoil all vith
eating Caudleâ€” me no give you any more Pysick be garâ€” you shall go to de Bethlem for meâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: What? do you say I am mad Varlet as Setting down his Grewel and rising up in great rage Mrs. Turbulent and Priscilla run hold him. thou artâ€” Hold me not; I will beat the Rogue's Eyes outâ€” Madâ€” madâ€”do you give me Physick to cure madness. Hah! am I madâ€” mad?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Be patient Timâ€”be patientâ€”I think the Caudle has made you cholleric.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: So now you vil se de effects off de Caudle, and off de yellow bile, de Coloreâ€”I say Maistre Turbulent you are mad, and vil be mad, and must go to de Betlem for de cureâ€”and so fare de vel. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Rogue, Dog, Rascal, Knave, does he come here to abuse me.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Thou wilt do thy self hurt to strain thy self after thy Physickâ€” thou shouldest not be angryâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Sawciness, what! must you be prating too with your thees and thous?â€” offers to strike her, is held by Mrs. Turbul. Let me aloneâ€”

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: I begin to be of the Doctors mind without a Syllogism; I think this is demonstration.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Good Tim. be not so angryâ€”and Turbulentâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I will be angryâ€” I will be Turbulentâ€” and I'll make ye all know your selves, and that I have the Spirit of Government, I will be angry you shall seeâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Turb.
sp.p: I think he's quite Mad â€” Mrs. Tur. and Pris. run rut, Mr. Turb. runs after them.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I think your Uncle is mad within, his Wife and his Daughter can hardly hold him: will you go in and see to pacifie himâ€” your Doctor Quibus has made him mad in telling him he would be madâ€” They are all together by the Ears, go in and part 'em.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Not Iâ€” the Divil part 'em for meâ€” I intend to make 'em madder Pol. before night, for I intend to make him drunk â€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Not now he has taken Physickâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Yes to choose â€” I hope the Doctor has purged away some of his Cholerâ€”good Pol. when you see the Coast clear give my Uncle this Note from meâ€” be sure you do not let my Aunt see it, nor any body elseâ€” be very private good Pol.â€” There's something for theeâ€” gives Money.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: He shall he sure to have it. But I can't imagine how you'll get forthâ€” there is to be a private meeting by and byâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for thatâ€” I know I have a Charm in the Noteâ€” Profitâ€”Advantage and Wine of free cost, that will bring him to me for all his Physick and his private Meeting â€” tho he were in the midst of his Railing, which he loves next to his Guts and Money. But be sure Pol. to have a care that my Aunt see you not give him the Noteâ€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I warrant youâ€” you know I am trustyâ€” (Calling within, Why Paulâ€”Paulâ€”Paulâ€”) You had best sow me to your Wast-Band, here's a deal of calling and bawling upon Paul.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why do they call thee Paul?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O! they have only turn'd my Heathen and Prophane Name, as they call it, of Pollux to Paulâ€” after they had taken me I was like to have been discharged when they heard my Name was Polluxâ€” hark, they call again â€” I must see what's the matterâ€” Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: O Mr. Furnish am I so happy as to meet you here! What have I done to you that you come not near my Shopâ€” is not Holborn in your way never?â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis a dangerous Hill Mrs. Slyâ€” I don't love to go that way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: You us'd to call often upon me when you went to your Taylors Mr. Snipwel in Fullers Rentsâ€” they say Mr. Furnish, you are very kind to his Wifeâ€” I protest I cannot but wonder you are so kind to an oldish Woman, as she is.â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I am kind to all, Mrs. Sly, old and young, fair and foul, all's one to me, when I'm in the humor; I have too much business to stand picking and choosing of Faces when I should need 'emâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: When shall you receive money Mr. Furnish, my Chicken bid me to call upon you for the 40 s. for Oyl, and Anchovies, and Olives and Capersâ€” it has been now above a Twelve Moneth on the Bookâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (Pox on her, I thought I had paid her sufficiently for that Score, and that she would not have the impudence to have asked me for this poor Sumâ€” what will this World grow to at last.) Faith Mrs. Sly, I had quite forgotâ€” I will call upon you one day or otherâ€” (I'll be even with this Jade for offering to ask me for Money.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Do Mr. Furnishâ€” you shall be heartily welcome.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But hark you Mrs. Slyâ€” I have been often told of your Husbands railing against the Times and the Government, openly in his Shop, as if behind the Counter were a Priviledge-place, speaks and talks at a strange rate of Railingâ€” I tell you on't for your good Mrs. Slyâ€” I heard it talkt of â€” I fear you'll be informed againstâ€” and try'd upon the Statute of Scandalum Magnatum.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Cannot Men speak in their own Houses but they must be troubled for it â€” is it not a very wicked Ageâ€” a dangerous timeâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But why cannot you let the times alone, Mrs. Sly, and follow your Vocations and your Meetings, and let the King and his Councillors aloneâ€” what is that to your Oyl and the Olives, or to the Mustard and Salt â€” I tell you out of kindness, does it bring in any profit?â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p:
Yes by it we are known to the Godly, and it is as good as
a Sign at the Doorâ€” my Shop is never emptyâ€”my Husband is an honest manâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay, this is something to the purpose, if you gain by railingâ€” but for your husbands honesty pray Mrs. Sly brag not of that; for the People say he is a great Wencher.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly,
sp.p: Out upon themâ€”He a Wencherâ€”I don't find he is so ableâ€” they bely him fearfullyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis true enough Mrs. Slyâ€” He spends abroad to my knowledge, which makes him so weak at home: You don't know what a sly man he is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Do not scandalize my Chickenâ€” He would not do such a thing for the whole World.

sp.speaker: (Fur.
sp.p: Nor you neither.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: He never goes out but to Meetings, I assure you. He haunts no ill placesâ€”not heâ€”as I know on.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: As you know onâ€” Why, do you think he'll let you know on't? when you think he is hearing Mr. Thumper and Mr. Long-Lungs, he is in disguise picking up Wenches in Moor-fields.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Well Mr. Furnish, You may talk, but he is no such manner of Manâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay if you won't believe me, will you believe your own eyesâ€” leave but the Shop to night, and dress your self up very modishly, put some Patches on those Pimples, and a Vizard Mask o're the face, and do you walk in the dark of the Evening this night, in the lower Walk, near the Old-Bedlam, and you shall see this precise Husband of yours, whom you think so devotedly hearing Mr. Long-Lungs, pick you up, and carry you to a Bawdy-House.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: I'll give you a good Dish of Anchovis if it be so: I protest I'll tryâ€” But I can't believe it.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Try Mrs. Sly, and call me a thousand Rogues if it be not soâ€” but be sure you go into the Popes-Head Tavern, and I'll be there to assist youâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: And so I willâ€” I'll see if he speaks truth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sly.
sp.p: How now Chicken, with whom have you left the Shopâ€” had not you patience to stay till I came home?â€”

sp.speaker: Rab. Sly.
sp.p: I left the Shop to be looked too by Brother Suck-Thumb, he's very honest, and I promised to send thee to him Chicken, that he may come to Mr. Turbulent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Out upon't, leave Mr. Ahednego Suck-Thumb in the Shop, he's got into another World by thisâ€” out upon't, he's looking in the Moon, not to the Shopâ€”(But I'll watch your water I'll warrant you â€” Exit

sp.speaker: Rab. Sly.
sp.p: Oh! it is the best and most diligent Wife as ever man had, Mr. Furnishâ€” she's so careful of her Shop she's worth Goldâ€”But Mr. Furnish, I think you have forgot the little debt you owe me for Commodities?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (Pox on him, he's dunning me too, but I'll stop his mout â€¢ â€”) I will pay it shortly Mr. Sly, I had forgot it indeed; but Mr. Sly, I hear a very ill report of your Wife, that she is continually railing against the Court-Ladies, and calls Westminster Sodom and Babel, preaches Lectures behind the Counter against Patches and Painting, and against the Pride and the Vanity of the Ladies of the other end of the Townâ€” and calls her betters Jezabels and Strumpetsâ€” Mr. Sly, I am afraid she will be inform'd againstâ€”

sp.speaker: Rab. Sly:
sp.p: Alas poor Chicken!â€”she thinks no hurt, she does it out of pure zealâ€” Oh the iniquity of the times! â€” they are very enormous times truly Mr. Furnish.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Ay indeed, Mr. Sly, so they are, for People to pretend to Religion and have none, to go to Meetings and cheat at home, to speak against Swearing and Lye all day long, to Rail against Whoredom openly, and Kiss a Sister in privateâ€” very enormous times Mr. Slyâ€”

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Nay, they are the Wicked that do so.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay, they are the pretended sanctified Brethren that do so.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Why do you accuse the good People so falsly? do you think they are like you?

sp.speaker: Fur,
sp.p: No Mr. Sly, I do that openly which you do privately, your Conscience knows that â€” but it is an abomination, yea a very great abomination and vileness in me, but in you 'tis but a backsliding, a slip and frailty of Nature.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Your Uncle will not own you in these accusationsâ€” I shall let him know you are of a vile spiritâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: In the mean time I will let you know that your dear Chicken knows how to be even with you Mr. Sly.

sp.speaker: Rab. Sly.
sp.p: Even with me! for what?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Oh, Ohâ€”you know for what: she knows when to take her timesâ€” when you are hearing Mr. Windy and Mr. Little-sence, she knows how then to take a turn in Moor-fields, or so.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Oh! this is intollerableâ€” don't scandalize my Chicken so, you had not bestâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why this 'tis to be incredulousâ€” believe your own eyes, you are to go to the Meeting to night â€” when she thinks you fast, and you suppose her in the Shop, you may find her here walking in the lower Walk by the Popes-Head Tavernâ€” and will take a Collation or so.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Can this be true Mr. Furnish, (And why mayn't she transgress as well as I?â€”) I have a good mind to be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis true as I tell you, I know those who have met her drest up in her Sunday-Cloathes, perfum'd with Rose-Cakes, a flaunting Tower on her head, and all those shining Pimples in her face, hidden under black Patches, a yellow Hood, and a Vizard to keep her self unknownâ€” And in this very dress, if you please, you may meet her this night about twilight.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I would willingly satisfie my selfâ€”sure Chicken does not serve me so.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Come to me at the Popes-Head Tavern, and I'll furnish you with a Wigg, Hat and Campain Coat turn'd up with blew, so that she may not know youâ€” and you shall pick her up your self, and bring her to the Tavern and be convinc'd that I tell you no lyeâ€”

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: And I willâ€” 'tis a business of much concernâ€” if it be so, I find her Nature is frail, and she is not yet so perfect as I took her to be. Well Mr. Furnish, I'll meet you at the timeâ€” but I can't believe that Chicken is false to me. I'll go into Mr. Turbulentâ€” Exit.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: So he's gone to exercise his Lungs with my Uncle Turbulent, to Rail against the Government, and the abominable Prophanation of the Times, and to speak Treason in their little private Conventicleâ€” He's a sweet Saint, but I hope to be even with him. Enter Mr. Cringe.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I see this is a dangerous place for me to enter into, here's dun after dunâ€”I can't shun him â€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Mr. Furnish hey, your most humble Servant Mr. Furnish, 'tis a rare thing to see you heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why so Mr. Cringe, I am not such a Monster.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: No, but you are never at homeâ€” I have been at your house 40 times hey, and can never meet with you heyâ€” I thought you had been a man of your word heyâ€” did not you promise me the 100 Pound you owe me heyâ€” without fail at Christmass last heyâ€” and now it is July heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (I must put him besides this discourse) If you call on me to morrow or next day Mr Cringe, I will give you a Bill upon a Banker in Lumbard Street; but pray Mr. Cringe, how goes squares between my Cozen Lucia and youâ€” when are you to be Married Manâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Why Mr. Furnish, 'tis a secretâ€” but I'll tell you, it is sooner than she thinks for heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: That's pretty, Marry and she not know itâ€”what, you have got another Missâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: No, I have got a Licence ready, and Mr. Turbulent has promised I shall be married to her to morrow hey, He'll make her consent hey.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But do you think she loves you Mr. Cringe?

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Oh yes, she loves me hugely hey.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Then you have the Art of Courtshipâ€” she's wittyâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: The Art of Courtship heyâ€” I court her after the best and newest way of Courtship hey.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Why in brave Heroick Verseâ€”heyâ€”just as the great Heroes do in the Play-House heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Then I see Mr. Cringe, you steal privately to Plays in the Afternoon, after you have been at a Meeting in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I go only to see Civil, Heroic Plays heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Indeed that is a most excellent fashionable way of making Love. I'll tell you there is a Gentleman that I know, who is about to put all Cook upon Littleton into Heroicks, not blank Verse but Rimes, and would have engaged me to have spoken to my Lady Medler to get an order that the Lawyers should plead in Verseâ€” why I think they might as well go to Law in Rime, as make Love in Rime, 'twould make the Lawyers the more satyrical.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: That would be excellent. Cook hey! I'll have that Cook when it comes out hey.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: But Mr. Cringe, shan't I see some of your Poetryâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I have a Copy of Verses here, but they are not finished hey, and tho I say it, they are the best Heroicks that ever were wrote hey, and that's a bold word hey. pulls Papers out.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I hope they are not longâ€” I do not love long Stories in Verse.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: No, they are but a few heyâ€” but you may judge by them, 'tis a Dialogue between Mrs. Lucia and my self hey.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: A Dialogue: Oh! I love discoursing in Verse, 'tis excellentâ€” come read itâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: You must know hey, that Mrs. Lucia in a cross fit hey, would have had me not to love her heyâ€” and you shall see how I have answered her heyâ€” I protest in as high straines as ever were writ hey.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Pox on your preambles; read 'emâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Nay, I must make you understand heyâ€” look ye hey, Lu. Well.â€” stands for Lucia Well-bred; and Fin. Crin. for Finical Cringe heyâ€” now mark yeâ€” Fin. Crin. beginsâ€”hemâ€”Reads
Loves fire within me does so fiercely glow,
My heart flames out in Sacrifice to you,
Your pity which can never do you harm,
Will keep you from consuming like a Charmâ€” Mark that heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Very goodâ€” a high strain.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Now Lu. Wellâ€”repliesâ€”hemâ€”
If common pity will your pain relieve
That is an Alms I'll not refuse to give,
But could I Sir, resemble your desires,
In answering them with the like scorching fires;
We our own executioners should prove,
And burn up one another with our love.
Mark that heyâ€” is it not excellent hey?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: By my Faith (as Ben Johnson says) a very high vapour, 'tis a strain beyond Ela Manâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Hemâ€”hemâ€” now Fin. Crin. replies,
The flame of Love no water can asswage,
It makes it blaze and roar with fierce and rage. Now Lu Well.â€” againâ€” markâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I doâ€” (that you are a Ninny)

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
'Tis 'cause you don'tâ€”
Fling on fresh Buckets at a faster rate,
A close supply its fury will abateâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: She gives you good Counsel Mr. Cringeâ€” but what's that half Verse, for with a long scratch was your Muse jadedâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis the fashion to write soâ€”in imitation of Virgilâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Whether there be any reason for it or noâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
