Prethe let me go onâ€” you'll forget the sense hey, Mark how I answer hey, now Fin. Crin. again,
I'm quite tyr'd out, just like an o'retyr'd Beast
That's sinking, being with too much weight opprest.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Alas poor weary Assâ€” an excellent Simileâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Nay, Mark what Lu. Well. saysâ€”
Then you should out aloud for succour cryâ€”
To ease you in this sad necessity.

Then Fin. Crin. replies with a smart Repartee heyâ€”
Oh! 'tis you only that can succour give,
And reaching out to death can make me live.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: That's beyond my comprehension.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Mark againâ€” Lu. Well.â€”Speak thenâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why what have you been doing all this while, that she bids you speak now? have you been talking all this while Incognito?

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Pray Mark, You are so Criticalâ€” hey
Speak then, And you shall see that I will prove
So kind, to give you any thingâ€” but Loveâ€”

Do'ye Mark that long Pause hey, 'tis fine that, and modish, as she had granted me all things, and then to dash it all with a But again, But Loveâ€” hey is not that fine â€” But then Mark how I answer. Fin. Crin.â€”

But Loveâ€” Mark the long pause again hey
But Loveâ€” And that's the only thing I crave,
Without it I were better in my grave.
Is not that an excellent conclusionâ€”heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why I thought you said you had not concluded them.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I do intend to make it longer hey, but for the present heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But for the presentâ€” they are long enough of Conscience, but I must tell you Mr. Cringe, that you are a very Plagiary, and have stole this most excellent Dialogue out of a Play eall'd Loves Triumphâ€” I see you deal in Plays as well as Sermons Mr. Cringe.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I protest I am the most unfortunate man alive Mr. Furnish, 'tis a very Thievish Age, for that Author stole 'em from me heyâ€” or else our fancies jumpt together heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: It may be so Mr. Cringeâ€”well I must take my leave of youâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Pray don't speak of these Verses to Mrs Lucia heyâ€” I will surprise her with 'em heyâ€” your Servant Mr. Furnish, your very humble Servantâ€” with many foolish and antick bowsâ€”Exit.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Go thy ways for a silly, finical, conventicling, versifying Ninne-hammer. Enter Lucia.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Cozen Luciaâ€” how is't? God give you joy Couz, I hear you are to be married to morrow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: (How the Devil came he to know that) Yesâ€”fo I am to dayâ€” and will be till I am married; who told you so?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Your own dear Loveâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: (Sure he was not so impudent) My Love who's that?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why he that's to marry you to morrow, Mr. Cringe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: (Oh is it there, I had like to have committed a mistake) that's suddenly indeed, and I know nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis a Secret C â€¢ uz. but you see I make none of it to youâ€”the Pop has got a Licence ready, and my Uncle has promised him to morrow, but I think you have more wit than to have such a Ninny.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I thank you Cozen Furnish for this discovery, I see he drives hard, but I will prevent itâ€” I must take another course with this Coxcomb, and play the fool with him no longer.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Did not you tell me Couz. that you would let me see my Uncles Armour of Brown Paperâ€”But you are a Wag, and put it upon himâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: In truth Couzen Furnish I told you no lye, for he spoyl'd me thtee Silver Thimbles in making it, and spent me 6 d. in Needlesâ€” He work'd harder than a Taylor before East r at it, for 6 Weeks lock'd up close in the Garrat, it is his own handy work every stitch on't, I'll assure youâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But what is it for?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You know he is terribly affraid of being laid up, or sent to Prison, for his Treasonable Speeches, his guilty Conscience tells him he deserves it, and though there's no danger at all, he and his Visioner has fram'd such dreadful fancies in their Heads, that he is afraid of his own shadow, and every noise of the Car-Men in the Street makes him fear a Massacre, or a Pursevant, and I know not what melancholly Chimera's.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But could he not have bought him Arms.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh noâ€”His Covetousness would not let him do thatâ€” besides he was affraid he should have been suspected for a Plotter, if Arms had been found in his House.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But brown Paper would be but small defence to either Sword or Bullet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I assure you he has made it Pistol Proof very near, and as to a Sword 'tis impenetrable.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Fore Gad I long to see these famous Arms.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And that you shall at night, and him in 'em, if you will but disguise your self like a Pursevant, or an Officer of the Guards, and get two or three Red Coates, and Musquets and Bandeleers, with which â€¢ e'll furnish Hangby, Pol and one or two more, like Souldiers â€” and let me alone to fright him into his postureâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur:
sp.p: Faith, I have a design upon him, before night, but this pleases me so well, that I won't miss itâ€” in the mean time Couz farewel â€” you shall see me at nightâ€” Exitâ–ª

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well Pol. what says Doctor Quibus?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: He says he will be with you instantly, and swears Morble â€¢ , the whole House is mad besides your self.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That's wellâ€” 'Tis to prove 'em mad I send for himâ€” didst get the Certificate drawn fair that I scribl'd o'reâ€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, there 'tisâ€” Gives Paperâ€”Reads.â€”

This is to Certify all whom it may concern, That Mr. Timothy Turbulent, now dwelling in the lower Square in Moor-fields is not Compos mentis, but is de straught of his Senses, and fit for to be placed in the Charitable Hospital of Bethlem for Cure.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I think 'tis well enough, this I'm sure Dr. Quibus will sign to, and for a Guinny I know I can have Doctor Plush's Hand.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Ay, and that you and all the House are mad too for another Guinny.

div.stage: Enter Suck-Thumb, walking on the Stage with his Hat over his Eyes and Arms across.

sp.p: Peace be unto yeeâ€” Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And to you alsoâ€”There goes the Seerâ€”do they meet to day Polâ€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Ayâ€”ayâ€”they are going to exercise; Mr. Rahshecca is there alreadyâ€”But I shall shorten their Meeting by and byâ€”I'le spoil itâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Oh, I have a Note from Mr. Furnish to fetch him to the Popes Head-Tavernâ€”His good, dear Nephew knows how to charm himâ€”But my old Mrs. must not know on'tâ€” Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But I'le tell her on't, and send her like an Harpie among 'umâ€”when they are in the midst of their sportâ€”

div.stage: Enter Cringeâ€”singing fal la la la

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh here's my finical faâ€”laâ€”I'le make him change his Note instantlyâ€”I must leave fooling with this Fool.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: [with many antick Ducks and Cringes] your Servant Madam Lucia, I kiss your fair hands heyâ€”Mr Turbulent is going to be busie hey, and so I left him hey.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And so am Iâ€”therefore pray leave me tooâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I am not so ill-bred Madam Lucia heyâ€”what to leave a fair Lady hey, and my Mrs. hey.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mr. Cringe take notice that I leave you now for altogether; and that the Farce between us is ended: I am quite tyred with your Puppet-play, and I will have no more on't.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I don't understand you Madam Lucia heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then I'le make you understand me hey â€” mark me, if from this instant you ever come ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ offer me any of the paultry Heroicks, or to make love to me, or to speak, say, or pretend, that I am your Mistress, or offer so much as by dumb show, or with your grimaces to make any Court to me: If I can not beat thee my self, I will have thee soundly lambasted, and well-favourdly kicked by some body elseâ€”do you understand me now.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: This is very plain heyâ€”you are but in jest sure heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You had not best put it to the Tryalâ€”youl find I am in earnestâ€” and that I tell you this in true, keen, and downright lambicks, which is better than all your silly Heroicks.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Umhâ€”this is tart heyâ€”quite forsake me hey â€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, for rll you have got a License heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: (Oh this wicked Mr. Furnish has told her of the License and spoiled all.)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Come I'le advise you for old acquaintance sake, since you have been at the charge of taking out a Licence, tis but scraping out my name Lucia Well-bred, and putting in my Cousin. Priscilla Turbulent, and all will be well again. She loves you, and there is 500 l. in Mr. Furnishes hand put out for her to my knowledgâ€”Go I say, Court her, and get her; the business is half done alreadyâ€”for I swear to you Mr. Cringe, I would sooner lose all my
portion, and let my Uncle Turbulent take it, than be married to such a simple, nonsensical, sinical Ass as you are.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: This is very plain Mrs. Well-bredâ€”heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis very true Mr. Cringeâ€” (oh here she comes, if I could make these Extreams meet 'twould be excellent, and out of their disagreement frame an harmonious sound I should be a shee-Orpheus.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: (I have a good mind to Court Mrs. Priscilla in very spightâ€”that may make her come about heyâ€”)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Cousin Priscilla I have been speaking a good word for you to Mr. Cringe hereâ€”he says he loves you very much â€” and I know you love him, he has many good parts: why should you not know one another betterâ€”Long Courtships, out of fashionâ€”come Mr Cringe speak to her.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: And so I will heyâ€” (I don't care a pin for you Mr. Lucia fa la la la fal la la ly do you think I doted on you To Mrs Lucy aside sings heyâ€”you are mistaken hey, and I will have Mrs. Priscilla, and she shall have your Portion heyâ€”how do you like that heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ay, ay, if you can get itâ€” Exit.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: (aside) I have a great fancy and desire for this man.
I like his fine, airy humour; it will do well to mix with my heavy temper. I had best provide for my self whilest I may.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Do you love me Mrs. Priscillaâ€”hey

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Thou sayest so.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: But I would have you say soâ€”heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Plainly if it would do thee any good to know it; verily I have a kindness for thee.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: That is well heyâ€”and I will also be kind to you from this time forthâ€”hey

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: I (I have soon made an end of the business hey, this is to the purpose hey. I can round, round, like a horse in a Mill with Mrs. Lucia hey, and am now where just where I began heyâ€”A fig for Mrs. Lucia â€” I'le get Mrs. Priscilla in earnest if she will but love Heroicksâ€”)

sp.speaker: Crin,
sp.p: But Mrs. Priscilla shall I shew you some Versesâ€”won't you love Versesâ€”)

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: They are very vain and abomianble, and used only among the profane; they stink in the Nostrils of the Righteous.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Mrs. Priscilla we shall never agree if you will not let me write Heroicks, I shall never marry you.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: I had best yield to him till I am married, and then I may convert him from that Pagan Trick of Versifying.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I will write Hymns and Lamentations.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Thou sayest wellâ€”plainly that will be very agreable to my dispensationâ€”ha mayest write Hymns of Lamentation whilst the good people are under persecution.
(Calling within Pris. Pris. why Pris.) My mother calleth) Finical Cringe, I shall be passing, but I am thine in the Love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: So, I have made a short hand of it hey â€” I shall get Mr. Turbulent's Daughter, and Mrs Lucia's Portion, for she'll Marry Mr. Fairlove hey, and then her Uncle won't give her a Groar heyâ€” and so I shall have allâ€” for he has no body else to give it to heyâ€” a fig for Mrs. Lucia, hey, fal la la fa la la fa laâ€” Exit Singing.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Turbulent, Sly, Suck-Thumb and Pollux.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Where is your Mistress Paul?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: In her Chamber Sir.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: What is she doing?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Cutting her Cornes.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Then she intends to go abroad to nightâ€”where is my daughter?

sp.speaker: Pol
sp.p: In her Chamber, reading a piece of Aristotle's Logick, call'd Problems, or hard Questions

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Where is my Neece?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: She is in her Chamber at work.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: They are all well employ'dâ€”go Sirrah, see that the Doors be lock'd fast and bolted, let the outer Windows be shut up, that the sound of the Voice may not go forthâ€”and be sure to stand at the Door that no body interrupt us, and give us notice if any come nearâ€”be you on your watch Sirrahâ€”'tis dangerous times friends, and 'tis wisdom to be cautious. Brother Suck-Thumb set downâ€” Exit Pol. Come set down, this is the most They set Suck. Thumb pulls his Hat over his eyes, and puts his thumb in his mouth, leaning his elbow upon his other arm private Room in the House we may speak free. â€” Are not these sad times Brother Rabsheka, that we must skulk thus in holes and cornersâ€” Oh the good times of Nerva, when every one might think what he pleased, and speak what he thought, and never be questioned fort oh that was a gracious Heathen Emperorâ€”

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Or the good times of the Rump, when any one might rail against Kingly Government, and the idols of Monarcy, without check or controul. I tell you Brother Turbulent, it is a great tribulation to have ones zeal quenched â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Ay Brother, so that we are fain to whisper in the Closet, when we should cry on the house-tops

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Whilst the Nimrods, the Nebuchadnezzars, the Balshazers, and the oppressing Pharaohs ride in their Chariots, and on their Horses.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Whilst the Jezabels and the Athalias run about like wild Colts, snuffing up the Wind.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: And yet we must be silent and our mouths must be muzzled that we may not bray against those sad abominationsâ€” But I will speak, and I must speak, and I cannot but speak against Monarchy, which is the very tail of the Beast, that arises up with seven heads out of the Bottomless Pit.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis the Idol of the World and ought to be pull'd down, and laid in the Dustâ€”It must be overturn'dâ€”overturn'dâ€”overturn'dâ€”

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: For it permits the wicked and abominable men to do what is good in their own eyesâ€” and suppresses the fiery zeal, and the zealous fury of those who stand up for Reformation.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: And suffers the gathering together of Minstrels, and the noise of the Flutes, and the tinkling Cymbals in the Streets.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: And the Mor â€¢ is-dancers and the Rope-Dancers, the Puppet-Playsâ€”the Bull-bating, the Bear-bating, the Horse-Races, and the Cards, and the Dice, oh abominable!

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: And the Players of Interludes, and the Men and the Women singers.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: But Babylon must fall â€” must tumble, must be pulled downâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: And it shall fall, and it shall tumble, and it shall be pulled downâ€” Suck-Thumb groans once or twice. peace, brother Suck-Thumb has seen a Vision, he is about to speakâ€” Br â€¢ ther Abednego what hast thou seenâ€” He lifts up his Hat gravely.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I was carried out of this carnal body into the World in the Moon and there I beheld a great Tree, whose Branches overspread the face of the earth. On the top of this Tree sat an Eagle, and a Crown upon his Head â€” And there came a mighty Dragon out of a River, running at the foot of this Tree, and Fire came out at his mouth, and he devoured the Tree, and the Eagle thereon.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh wonderful! hast thou the interpretation of this Vision given to thee?â€”

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Not yetâ€” it may be revealedâ€”

div.stage: Enter Pollux gives Mr. Turbulent a Note, he goes aside and reads.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis from my Nephew Furnish, I hope he has got some money for meâ€” Dear U â€¢ cle, I must needs speak with you about a very great concern and advantage to you. I am at the Popes-Head-Tavern, near your house, where I have got ready a Pottle of butter'd Sack, because I heard you had taken Physick; make hast, and let not my Aunt know of it. Your loving Nephew Furn. Friends I have a very great concern that calls me away at this time, but we will meet againâ€”

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: And I have also at this time some extraordinary business to go to Mr. Furnish.

sp.speaker: Suc.
sp.p: Peace be with youâ€” I shall retire into the silence and waitâ€” Exeunt.

div.trailer: The End of the Second ACT.

div.head: The Third Act. The Scene a Tavern.
div.stage: Enter Furnish and Hangby dress'd, with a broad brimm'd Hat, cropt Hair, little Band, broad skirted Doublet, close knee'd Breeches, a little black Cloak, faced down, &c.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: WHy, thou art dress'd in Quirpo â€” and so metamorphozed, that no body can know thee â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: The right Cut of an Amsterdam Brother â€”

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: But you must alter your Voice â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I have the right twang of the Nose â€” let me alone for both whine and goggle.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Thou art a pure Rogue â€” what shall your name be?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Oh! Peregrine Pricket â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: It sounds well â€” this Uncle of mine is at his Exercise, he'll hardly be here yet this hour.
Oh, here's Grin Sneak, he won't know you in this Dress, â€” let's sport with the Fool a while.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Are you busie Mr. Furnish? â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: No Grin. â€” (Aside to Sneak) Oh Sirrah, I have met with one of the rarest Fellows in the World for Projects; â€” but he is a Stranger, and you may make your self by him â€” he wants some body to promote his Business.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Say you so â€” let me alone for that â€” you know my Lady Medler is my true Friend â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Mr. Peregrine Pricket, pray know this Gentleman, Sir â€” he is of my Acquaintance â€” you'll find him a very ingenious Man, and one who is a great Vertuoso, and lover of Rarities â€” one that has spent his whole Life in sinding out rare Inventions.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: You give him a friendly Character â€” Sir, your humble Servant â€” I am blunt, Sir, and a Traveller. embraces

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, I shall be happy in the Acquaintance of such an ingenious man, as I understand you are: I have made it my business Sir, to find out many things for the good of the Commonwealth â€” But of all, I am pleas'd with one thing that I am now undertaking, that will make England happy, and will cause the Act of Burying in Woollen to be repealed.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: That would do well, and be a great ease to the Heart of many an old Woman, who weeps and laments o're her lace Cut-work Smock, that has been laid up in Lavender for fifty years, to be buried in, and now must be wrapt in Woollen.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Indeed that is a beneficial Project â€” but I have one that will be much more beneficial to my self, and to all the Land of England, Scotland and Ireland â€” I can take a Partner in with me; and yet upon the dividend reserve 20000 pounds to my selfâ€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: (â€” Oh God, this is a rare Fellowâ€”I will get in with himâ€”) Mr. Pricker (I think Mr. Furnish calls you) pray let us confer Notes together over a glass of Wine â€” Knocks â€”
Sirrah, fetch a Bottle of the best Claret â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Jack, if my Uncle Turbulent comes to enquire for me, give me notice â€”

sp.speaker: Boy,
sp.p: I shall Sir. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: This Rogue has not Money to pay for this Bottle of Wine, and yet the joy of meeting this Projector, has put him into a Rapture, and given him some Confidence â€” who else is the sneaking'st Puppy in the World â€” Aside
Well Gentlemen, sit down, and be plain with one another like friends.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I shall not be thy Servant â€” look you here Sir, do you see this Lock of curious fine Flax, of which they may make Sisters Thread â€” and yet this Flax is made of the coursest Hemp in England â€”

div.stage: Pulls out a Lock of fine Flax, wrapt up in a Sheet of Paper.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, 'tis very fine â€” but when I was in Flanders, I met with a certain Dutchman, that made just such out of Nettle Stalks, and was crying an hundred pound weight of Nettle-Seed, to sow all the Fields about Bruges, of which he intended to make the finest sort of Cambricks â€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: That was extraordinary â€” of this Sir, I intend to make fine Holland, and by which I shall get de claro, sixty pound a week, and so improve the Manufacture of Linnen in England that it shall be so plentiful within a few Years, that they shall be glad to bury it again under ground.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Mr. Peregrine, I think now he will out-do you â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Pray Sir, I confess he goes beyond me in Manufactures; but I assure you, I can go beyond him, or any man else at the Handycraft Trade. I have made a Wimble to bore Hairs, which I can do so exactly, by the help of a Microscope, that it caused the great Admiration of several Vertuoso's

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: But of what use can that be? I love things that are beneficial to a Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Oh Sir, they are to make treble Flagellets for Ladies, that they may not spoil their mouths with the great ones â€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: But this is but of little benefit to your self â€” mine will bring me in 60 l. a week â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p:
That I confess was by the by; but my great Project that
will make us both rich, and which I have been this 17 years about, is an admirable Flea-trap, a Benefit the Commonwealth never yet received from all the Vertuoso's.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: But the Profit as to us still? â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I'll make it plain to you â€” there are so many thousand Houses in England, now every House shall have one of these Traps for 1 s. a year, which I will be bound to furnish them with; now what Family in England would not be glad to have such a Trap, to catch all their Fleas? They would think it the best shilling that ever was given in their Lives, and pay it willinglier than Hearth-moneyâ€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: 'Fore Gad, 'tis a rare Invention, and exceeding beneficial! but have you made Tryal of it?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Yesâ€”Yesâ€” I have a Compost of a strange faculty, which will draw all the Fleas in the House into the Trap â€” I made Tryal of it the other day for a Wager, and enticed a Flea out of a Ladies warm Bosom, which a Gentleman had made a Copy of Verses onâ€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: That was admirableâ€” I will speak to my Lady Medlar to get a Patent, that none shall make of these Traps for seven years but your self.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Why, that's it I would have, and judge you if there be but 500000 Houses in England (as there are the Lord knows how many more) and that we have twelve pence a House yearly, to what a brave Estate it will amount; and this also may be got for Scotland and Ireland, perhaps at 2 s. a Trap, because they want them more; you shall go halves with meâ€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: And I'll get it done for you I'll warrant you â€” I have great Interest at Court, and I'll make it my businessâ€” Aside. This was a happy encounter, and the most feasible and rationable I ever undertook.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Turbulent is below, shall I send him up?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Ay, ay â€” send him up Sirrah, is the Pottle of Butter'd Sack ready I spoke for?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Bring it up, and some Manchets to sop in it â€” shew these Gentlemen another Room, you Rogue. Go Gentlemen, and discourse your Affairs in the next Room, till I have occasion for you.
I must first mollifie the Heart of my dear Uncle, before I can attempt my Business, and he will not drink with Strangers â€” Oh here comes the Sick Man â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Coughs, ughâ€”ughâ€”ughâ€” Nephew, you are a strange man, to send for me out of Doors, when I have taken Physick, ughâ€”ughâ€” ughâ€” I fear I have gotten Cold already, that I haveâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Come Uncle, I have got some good butter'd Sherry; 'tis the best thing in the world after an Emettic. Boy, bring Wine and Manchets. Exit

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Your Docter Quibus thinks I'm mad, and gives me Pills of Hellebore to cure meâ€”Let me tell you, he's a very ignorant abusive Fellow, that he is.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: A mere Quackâ€”but he has rare medecines. Come let him goâ€” Uncle, here's a good draught to you â€” 'twill breed good bloudâ€” Drinks

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis pure good and comfortableâ€”'tis very hot Drinks and pauses But Nephew, what is the earnest business you sent for me about?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I'll tell you anonâ€” Drink off your Cup first; 'tis good to keep out the coldâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Well Nephew, I'll drink to youâ€” (Drinksâ€”) 'tis very extraordinary goodâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I'm glad you like it, Uncleâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: But Nephew, when shall I have the 500 l. you have promised me. If none thrive better by merchandizing than I did, there will be few Aldermen.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Well Uncle, I shall pay you all very shortly with 30 per cent. Interestâ€”You will see me in a very fair way to be Lord Mayor of London.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Would I could, Boyâ€”I always had a kindness for theeâ€” (Drinks, Furnish fills his Cupâ€”) 'Tis so hot it makes me sweat.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (It begins to make him glow alreadyâ€”How he sucks it down!â€”) 'Tis very good Uncle; you don't drinkâ€”Come a Health to my Aunt.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Pish, an old woman without teethâ€”I'll drink no Healths; but if you'll begin a Remembrance to my Lady Medler, I'll pledge youâ€”Oh that's a very loving Lady, and the best of a Court Lady I ever met with.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Come away then, here's to her.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I'll think of her. Drinks all.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: He begins to be warm. (Fills again.) Come Uncle, t'other dish, and I'll tell you my business.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Come then, under the Rose, to your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Well remember'dâ€” Bravely doneâ€” I'll pledge you a Brimmer. Fills Cups again.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Truly methinks it has done me goodâ€”hemâ€”hemâ€”'tis a very excellent Creatureâ€” it cheers the heartâ€” you can't think how light I amâ€”But your business?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I am always studying your good Uncle â€” A Cat does not watch so diligently for a Mouse, as I do for opportunities of serving youâ€”Nay If you won't drink I won't tell you any more.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I do Nephewâ€”come what is it? Drinks.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I have met with a Gentleman of Cumberland one Mr. Peregrine Pricket, who has been in Holland these 7 years; his Father was a great Olivarian, and he is of the right stamp a Commonwealths man; his father died this last Christmass, and has left him 400 l. a year, which he is now going to take possession of.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: And what's all this to me? Drinks.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay, if you han't Patience to hear â€” why, he's a Batchelor, and wants a Wife; I having a great Intimacy with him, have recommended my Cousin Priscilla to him, and let him know, I had 500 l. of hers in my Hand, put out for her Portion â€” and he promised me to meet me here by and by â€” for which end I sent for you, that you might see him, and discourse about it.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Four hundred pound a year say you â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Ay, four hundred pound a year, and one also to your hearts wish â€” He has been bred up so long in Amsterdam, that he says, the very smell of Monarchical Air, makes him sick, and is ranker in his Nostrils than Lamp Oyl, or stinking Butter.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: That's a man cut out for me â€” but will he rail bravely against the Times? Hah! may a man speak freely to him without fearâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur
sp.p: Oh, 'tis his whole delight; 'tis the true Liberty of a Butter-Box â€” He'll speak against Governors and Magistrates, as if they were Scavengers or Chimney-sweepers â€” and as reverently of Princes and Lords, as if they were Tapsters and Hostlers â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: A rare Fellow â€” I love him already â€” but you know Prist. is a Quaker â€” how will he like that?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p:
'Twill please him the better, he is a Muggletonian; and as for manners, has as little as any Quaker of them all, and as for Thee and Thou, he says, it was the Language of Adam and Ev â€¢
â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: A rare Fellow indeed â€” better and better (Drinks.) Well Dear, Dear, loving Nephew, I can't but hug thee for this news â€” This w llcome Tidings, and the good Wine has chear'd my Heartâ€” Come Nephew, have you forgot all your Old Songsâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: No Uncle, I will sing any that you like.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh sing the Hymn of the High-way-man â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What â€” I keep my Horse, I keep my Whore?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I, thatâ€” thatâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (So now it begins to work â€” what pains am I fain to take, to open the close-lock'd-heart of this covetous Uncle of mine) well i'll sing it Uncle.

q.l: I keep my Horseâ€” I keep my Whore,
I take no Rents, yet am not poor â€”
I travel all the Land about,
And yet was born to never a foot
With Partridge plump, and Woodcock fine

I do at Midnight often dine; Turbulent sets himself in an antick Posture, staring with his eyes, and holding his hands like a Changeling, singing after him all the whileâ€”nodding his Head up and down.
And if my Whore b â€¢ not in Case,
My Hostess Daughter takes her Place.
The Maids sit up, and watch their turns;
If I stay long the Tapster mourns.
The Cook-maid has no mind to sin,
Tho' tempted by the Chamberlain:
But when I knock, Oh how they bustle,
The Hostler yawns, the Geldings justle;
If Maid but sleep, Oh how they curse her,
And all this comes of deliver your Purse Sir.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh that once again, dear Nephew â€” Sings, but when I knock, &c.â€” Furnish knocks and whispers the Drawer.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (Bid the Gentlemen in the next Room come in, I have wrought him up to the right Cue â€”now can I mould him like Wax.)
Oh Uncle, here's the Gentleman I spoke to you of.
Mr. Peregrine Pricket â€” your Servant Sir â€” This is my Uncle Sir I spoke to you of.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Sir I shall be happy to be made known to you.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I have heard of your worth Sir, by my good Nephew, here, will you sit Sir, and do as we do? I was not very well, and my good Nephew has provided for me some butter'd Sack â€” Sir, here's to you. Drinks.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Mr. Furnish has promised to furnish me with a Commodity that I want â€” a Wife Sir â€” and has told me of a Daughter of yours, Mrs. Priscilla, I think he call'd her, a very Religious and Godly Virgin â€” 'Tis my desire, Sir, to marry into a Religious Familyâ€” I am newly come to my Estate, and will settle 200 l. a year Joynture: As for her Portion, I know it already, I dare take Mr. Furnishe's word for it.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I see Sir, we shan't be long a making up this Match; I like you, and your Estate, and you like me and the Portion; now if you and my Daughter like one another, the Business is done.

div.stage: Whilst they are talking, Furnish and Sneak go out.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: No question but I shall like her, I have heard so much of her many Excellencies and good Qualities; the worst that I know of her, is her Skill in Logic; I do not love to have my Wife have more Logic than I; she'll say or do any thing, and prove it by Logic.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Indeed you say trueâ€” I have told her often of it, and that she should not love Reason so well â€” Indeed I must confess, Logic is her worst fault â€” but when she is married, you'll find other Business for her than poring in Logic Books.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I was a while at School at Leyden, and if I can remember any of my Old Lessons, I'll Court her that way â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: that will win her Heart â€” but 'tis no matter, Mr. Pricket, I have the Spirit of Government, and steer the Helm of the Commonwealth in my own Family â€” she shall have you â€” like or like not â€”and it shall be as I pleaseâ€”I am the Speaker in my Family.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: But that will be too tyrannical to compell her â€” but if there be the major Voices of the Family, I think she may then be lawfully compelled â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You say very well, and it shall go by your Voices â€” I see you are a true Commonwealths-man â€” But we live in sad timesâ€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Ay, Times of Aegyptian Darkness.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Whilst Men eat, and drink, and rise-up to play â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Till their Eyes cannot look out with Fatness.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: They wallow in the Puddle of Filthiness.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: And roll themselves in the Sink of Sin â€” Oh, the Riotousness and Wickedness of this Age â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: The Villanies, the Whoredoms, the Fornications, the Adulteries, the Pride, Folly, and Vain-glory of this Age.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: This wanton, luxurious, exorbitant, abominable, scurrilous, cheating, bribing, cousining, and treacherous Age â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: This libidinous, licentious, lacivious, lying, lazie, latitudinarian Ageâ€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: (He has a most run me out of Breathâ€”He is too well practic'd at this sport) well Sir, in the mean time, here's to youâ€”I'll ha your Daughter, and Joynter her bravelyâ€”

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Oh Sir. Mr. Furnish is taken below with an Execution, and the Serjants are having him away to Prison â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: What ill Chance is thisâ€”just as I am about the preferment of my Daughterâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Uncle if you don't help me at this pinch I am undoneâ€”I had got Money to have paid this, but only my promise to meet Mr. Pricket and you here made me neglect itâ€” Whispers Turbulent.
'Tis but for 50 l. don't spoil your Daughter's Fortune, and play the Fool to deny itâ€”He shall be bound with me to you for itâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You are a strange man that you areâ€”I protested and vow'd, I'de nere lend you any more, and yet you have such fetchesâ€”I think I'm bewitch'd with you.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Speak softlyâ€”don't spoil your Daughters Fortune for 50 l. he has 400 l. a Year, I know he'll be bound, but has no Money at presentâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: If he'll be bound with you and Mr. Sneak; I'll do it for this onceâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Thank you Uncleâ€”Well Serjants, if you'll go into the next Room and call for a Bottle of Wine, I'le give you a Note to receive the Money. and pay you for your Civilityâ€”

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: We will Sirâ€” Exeunt Serjants.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (Aside to Hangby) If I had not made him drunk, he would have let me agon to Tiburn, before he would have parted with 50 l. and spoil'd his Daughter Priscis Fortune to bootâ€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: But where hadst thou these counterfeit Serjants so readilyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Oh I had them ready at handâ€”I had lai'd my designâ€”now second meâ€”

Well Uncle, I have perswaded Mr. Pricket and Mr. Sneake to be bound with me to you in a 100 l. Bond for the payment of 50â€”I have a Blank Bond readyâ€”I'll fil it upâ€”and do you in the mean time draw a Note upon Mr. Scrible your Scrivener, that will serveâ€”

div.stage: Draws out Bond and Pen and Inkâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Well Nephew you are the strangest man, I know not how to deny you any thingâ€”but what time?â€”Nephew, set your day and be punctual. Strokes him on the head.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I'll desire it but for a Month, and you shall have 20 s. and a Collation when I pay it, for your kindness.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Well fill up the Bondâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Turbulent, Mr. Turbulent, I am sorry at heart, and grieved in Spirit to see you within the walls of a vile and abominable Tavernâ€”I am afraid it is as Dr. Quibus says, you are not in your right Senses, to set your foot within this unsanctified and Anti Christian House, this Image of Babel. Does not Anti Christ hang out at the door for a Sign, the very Image of the Beast, with his Trible Crown, and the Bush of the Babylonish Whore hanging before him: Oh Mr. Turbulent it is abominable, and you are become defiledâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What a mischief is thisâ€”the Devil has outwitted me, and sent this Furie before the Bond was seal'dâ€” Aside.

div.stage: Mrs. Turbulent runs to the Table, and snatches up the Bond.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: What is this you are doingâ€”are you entering indeed into more Bond â€¢ â€”Oh that wicked, cursed, abominable Nephew of yours, that will utterly undo you at last, and leave you not worth one groatâ€”He has already drawn you into so many Bonds and Obligations, that you'll have nothing ere long, but must be fain to beg thorow the Grate at Ludgateâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Good Aunt be pacifiedâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I won't be pacified, and he shall not be bound in Bonds, and I will see what it is, and I will look on it my selfâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You're an Ass, and Fool, meddle with your own matters, and go about your business, who sent for you hitherâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: This is my business, and this my matters, and I will see what 'tisâ€” Puts on her Spectacles, Mr. Turbulent standing in the middle, and Mr. Furnish and Sneak on each side with Hats off, Hangby at a distance as if amazed.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You're a Fool, 'tis Latin and you can't understand it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: You're a Coxcomb, I understand it as well as your selfâ€” but I'll tell you, 'tis the Language of the Beast, and one of the Confusions of Babel; reads Noverint universityâ€” Puts off her Spectacles when she speaks, then puts them on again every time.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Away you old doting Dunce, read the Condition let the Bond alone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I will not read the Condition, I will have no Conditions, and there shall be no Bonds; and if I can't read it I'll carry it to my brother Mopus of Grays Inn, and he shall read itâ€” Reads Noverint university; I thought what 'twas.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis not university.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis universityâ€”and the wicked, abominable universities, where the Youth are trained up in all the vile Languages of Babel.

div.stage: Falls into a Fit of Coughing; her Spectacles fall down.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: So her Eyes are gone, I hopeâ€”they are brokeâ€”would she were choak'dâ€”Good Aunt, drink a Glass of wine, 'twill stop your Coughing; you speak too fast.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I'll drink none of your unsanctified liquor of the Devil's brewing, that causes Drunkenness, Fornication, Whoredom, Adultery, Fightings, Brawlings, Cheatings, Trepannings, Cozenings, and all the villany and abomination that is committed in these lewd houses of Sin, Iniquity, and Pollutionâ€” Coughs againâ€” Oh get me a little waterâ€”

div.stage: Knock, Enter Boy. â€” hast thou any water in the house?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes very good, from Annisacleer, the best as ere you drank.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Fetch me some quicklyâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: You Rogue, bring up a Bottle of White-wine and a Beer-glass. â€”quickly Sirrah, no water. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Mr. Turbulent, I fear you cannot well steer the Helm of Government in your own family; Mrs. Turbulent is very rough, she seems not to be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I will let her alone here, but when she comes home I will reprove her in the heat of my zeal, and she shall be satisfied.

div.stage: Enter Boy and Wine, fills, gives to Mrs. Turbulent.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Here Aunt, here is a Glass of waterâ€”but I should think you had better drink wine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Not in this unhallowed placeâ€”I think this water is not very clear.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis very good, drink it up. She drinks it off.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis very good water, and relishes wellâ€”where do you get this water?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: We have it come into the Cellar in Pipes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: My Pipe-water is not half so good as this; Mr. Turbulent, I will have of the same water as this is, 'tis very pleasant tasted water.
sp.stage: Mr. Turbulent begins to heave as if he would vomit.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Turbulent, thou art overcome with the creature; thou hast committed vileness in the sight of the people, and drunk beyond thy measureâ€” Coughs again.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Hold your prating, you will spoil your Daughters prefermentâ€” Hark, I tell you the business. Whispers this.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Here Aunt, stop the coughingâ€” I hope 'twill mollifie the irascible quality. Drinks it up.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Oh this filthy Cough â€” it interrupts me â€” give me the Water â€” Drinks it up.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Would it would choak thee too for me â€” Is it not good Water? â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Oh 'tis very excellent Water â€” is it as Mr. Turbulent tells me? â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Yesâ€”Yesâ€” he has 400 l. a Year, and offers to Joynter my Cousin in 200 l. and you had like to spoil all â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Nay, if it be so, I shall rest satisfied â€” Coughs again.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (God a mercy Wine, she would not hear beforeâ€” I find it is of a mollifying Nature) give another Glass of Water to my Aunt; Doctor Quibus says it is very good against the Cough.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: And he is a very Learned Doctor, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Boy, Drawer â€” shew me another Room where there is a Bed, I must lie down a littleâ€”

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will Sir â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Lead me Boy â€” Exit with the Boy.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Bless me, my Uncle is stole out to take a Nap; if he grows sober, he'll ne're sign the Note I have drawn for the 50 l. â€” Come Hangby, let's follow him and get it done while he's in the Humor.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I do intend to make Mrs. Priscilla my wedded Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, I understand as much â€” I was too passionate, and did not understand your worth, and that you were not one of the wicked of the Earth; but selected from this Generation of Vipersâ€”

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: It was the Cause of Matrimony that drew me into this place, and engaged me into the Temples of the Ungodly â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs Tur.
sp.p: I am extreamly satisfied in your Behavior and Company â€” Where's Mr. Turbulent?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: He's gone to lie down a little on the Bed in the next Roomâ€” Let us get him to sign the Bond to my Uncle presentlyâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Mr. Pricket, let us go in to Mr. Turbulent â€” I will send for my Daughter Prisc. for once into the placeâ€”thou hast made the House of Uncleanness pure by thy Presence. Shew us the way, Nephew Furnish â€” Exeunt omnes.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Will you tell Mr. Furnish I am here, and desire to speak with him?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: presently Sir. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: I shall now see whether he accuses my Chicken falsly â€” I â€¢ m something hard of Belief â€” yet I may judge of her by my own Frailty; all Flesh is subject to back-sliding.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: You see I am come Mr. Furnish, I walk'd round the Walk and could not see my Chicken, I believe you scandalize herâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: That you shall know presentlyâ€”Boy, fetch me the Periwig Hat, and Coat I gave you to lay up.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I shall. Sir. Exit Boy.
You will find your error, Mr. Sly, that you should not believe your self a Cukold â€” Do you think your blew-apron'd Shopkeepers wives to be more chast than the Court Ladies?â€”I'll convince you.
sp.stage: Enter Boyâ€”they dress Sly with Wig, Coat, Hat;
sp.p: Nay, you shall have a Sword too, else perhaps she'll refuse youâ€”You shall have mine. Puts on his Sword.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: I think she can't know me.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: No, not if you alter a little the squeeking of your voiceâ€”You must speak littleâ€”You'll find her willing without much courtingâ€” Come hither Mr. Sly, look yonderâ–ªâ€” what think you of that Gentlewoman? Looks out at the door.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: I protest and vow 'tis tny Chicken, I know her by her amble; 'tis the right motion of her Buttocksâ€” I'll be with her â€” presentlyâ€” Exit Sly.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: So, you have the Note for the 50 l.

sp.speaker: Fur,
sp.p: Safe enough, Boyâ€” and will have the money to morrow morning; but where's my Aunt?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: She is within, and grown the kindest loving Soul as ever you knewâ€”I was fain to steal out to get a little breathâ€” she has sent for her daughter Pris too.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Go in again, I have a little business with this Gentlewoman; I'll come to you instantly. Exit Hangby.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Well Mr. Furnish, I have walk'd twice round and can't meet my Chickenâ€” there's never such a man as you describ'd him to be.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: No!â€”come hither Mrs. Sly, look yonder, what think you of that Gallant with along tail trailing after him? Looks out at the door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Ods heartlikins 'tis my Chicken, I know him by his Dogtrot and Spindle-shank'd Legsâ€”'tis he, I'll to himâ€”Have I caught you indeed! Exit.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Turbulent, Mrs. Turbulent, Hangby.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Come Nephew, why do you leave us? we can't be without your good company.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I was just a coming, having dispatch'd an affair of consequenceâ€”where's Mr. Sneak?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I have sent him for my daughter Prisâ€”Mr. Pricket shall see her, that he shall.
Oh here she comesâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Daughter, I have brought a Gentleman to be acquainted with youâ€”

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Nayâ€”thou hast sent for me to be acquainted with himâ€” thou makest not a true proposition.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Gossip, you had best tell me I lie.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: I say it not â€” thou mayst say it â€” But what seeketh this man?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Mrs. Priscilla, I seek thee for my wedded wife, that is the end of my seeking. What sayst thou, dost thou like me?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Thy proposition is not Hypothetical.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: But it is Hypothetical, and may be either Conditional, Copulative, or Disjunctive.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: He speaks rationallyâ€”thou sayst well, what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I am called Peregrine Prick â€¢ t.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: I like not thy name.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Are you chopping Logick indeed?â€”I'll make you like both his name and him too.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Pray Sir, be not in the postpredicament of oppositionâ€”she mistakes the genus of my nameâ€”But Mrs. Priscilla, nomen is quasi notamen, a certain Image by which the King is known, and is the vocabulum proprium whereby we name a thing; or vocabulum quodlibet, by which something is understood. I am called Peregrine Pricket, that is a Travelling Buck.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Thou hast spoken demonstratively, and I am reconciled to thy sense. But in what Relation dost thou stand?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: [This is a rare Wench, she'll do in Logic.] I shall tell you my business in a Categorical proposition.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Let it then consist as it ought, of one Subject, one Predicate, and one Copula.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Shitten come shites, leave your Moods and the Figures of your Copula's y'had best, and go to the business: do you like Mr. Pricket for a Husband?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Thy question may be determined universally, singularly, or particularly.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You're an universal, singular, and particular crack-brain'd Baggage, I'll make you know me and leave disputing. Offers to strike, is hindered.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: I fear thou art disguised, and hast taken too much of the creature, and drank of the polluted Springs which flow in these Cellars of the wicked. Enter Mr. Sly and Mrs. Sly.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Have I caught you indeed!â€”Oh you Harlot!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Have I found out your haunts you wicked whoremaster Rogue?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Oh you cunning Gipsie, this shan't serve your turn.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Oh you beastly Hypocrite! what make you in this disguise, with these Babylonish Garments, and the Sword of Perdition by thy side hunting after the Harlots in the twilight?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Oh you painted Jezabel, with the Devils Patches on thy Face, and the frizled Hair on thy Forehead, that standest here at the Corners of the Walls, to draw Young Men to Lewdness â€” Oh thou Midianitish Woman!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Oh thou lustful Zimri â€” Thou abominable Philistine!

sp.speaker: Slyâ–ª
sp.p: I thought thou had'st been looking to thy Shop.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: I thought thou had'st been hearing Mr. Windyâ€”

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Yes, you thought me safe enough, you Strumpet â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Ay, you thought me fast enough, you Villain.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Did I take pity of you for this, when you ran about to all the Meetings in Town, to get a Husband, and left off your vain Attire, and put your self into the precise Cut and Form â€” but I see you were a rank Hypocrite â€” Oh you lustful Woman â€” am I one to make a Cuckold of?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Away you pretended Zealot â€” let me tear out his Eyes â€” Falls on him, and pulls off his Wiggâ€” they hold her.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I am amazedâ€” Oh Mr. Rabshecah

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: â€” I am amused to see thee transformed into the Sh â€¢ pe of the Unrighteous; it will be a Scandal to all the good People: The Weekly Pamphlets will revile theeâ€” Oh Brother, thou art fallen â€”

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Why d'ye accuse me, that art worse thy self, I see thou art drunken, and wallowest in thy Iniquity â€” Was it for this Mr. Turbulent, you were in such haste to break up the Meeting, to come into this lewd place? â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Hah, hah, hah, hay â€” How these Hypocrites begin to lay open themselves! How often have they lick'd one another, as Bears do their Cubbs, into a shape of Sanctity; or as Horses, nabbing one another, with the Delight of railing at the Wicked? And nowâ€”
They turn their Insides outward, and appear in their true shapes â€” a formal Saint without, a very Beast within â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Mr. Prick â€¢ t, pray be not scandalized at these things â€” I perceive 'tis the Frailty of the Flesh, and they are both fallen from their first Station.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I so they are, they have found one another faulty, it is best to make up the Breach.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Phillipasly, Thou art in the same Predicament with thy Husband, you are both disguised, therefore thou oughtest not to exclaim, but let the matter be sifted by Division and Sub-division, that so the Truth may be found outâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Prittleâ€”prattleâ€”let me aloneâ€”leave me, don't hold me; let me come at the Whore-master-rogue; I will give him a Mark: I will strip him of his wicked Habiliments â€” Pulls off his Coat, Sword, &c.

div.stage: Enter Constables, with man of the House.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Come, take 'em away to Justice Right-or-wrong, away with 'em; do they come here to make a Disturbance, and to bring a Scandal upon my House? Away with 'em both Mr. Constable â€” the Justice will find out the matter â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Hah, hah, hahâ€” I think I am even with 'em Seise Sly, and Mrs. Sly â€” carry them forth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: This is the place of Confusion, I will retireâ€” Mr. Pricket, I hope you will come to my House; we shall there discourse matters betters â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I shall not fail to visit you â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Come Mr. Turbulent, let us depart in peace; I am sorry for the falling away of Brother Sly â€” his Gifts were many â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I will go with you â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Mr. Sneak, pray do the kind Office for me, as to wait on my Aunt home â€” I have a little Business with Mr. Pricket â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Nephew, good Night â€” Mr. Pricket, I shall be glad to see you at my House â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I shall wait on you to morrow â€” Exeunt all but Furnish and Hangby.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Ay, that you shall to nightâ€”you Rogue.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p:
This 50 l. was easily got, I was damnably afraid of it, when I saw the Dragoness my Aunt come in â€” Come in, I have another Shape to put thee in to night â€” Come awayâ€”
Fools are a Prey to Knaves, small Knaves to great,
Cullies to Gamesters; the whole World's a Cheat. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: The Fourth Act. The Scene Mr. Turbulent's House.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: WEll Frank, since 'tis so decreed; and that the Law of thy own Will has pass'd upon thee, I will be so much a Friend, as not to leave thee till I see the Execution of Matrimony executed.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And my Body fairly bestow'd in the Arms of Lucia.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Let it be so then; I'll see thee fairly noos'd, and then buried, and so I'll leave thee â€” The Report you have given me of this House, makes me afraid of Hobgoblins.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: They are all abroad, and my Angel Lucia left its Guardian only at this time.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I dread that Finical Fellow Cringe â€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Prethee learn to laugh at the Follies of the World as I do; for me thinks, nothing can be more ridiculous, than to see a man angry with Apes and Monkies, for acting their Natures; I tell thee they are made on purpose to make wise men laugh.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I know not what Temper my Spleen is made on; but they rather turn my Stomach, than make me smile. Enter Lucia.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You see, dear Lucy, I am diligent to obey your Commands.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You do but set me a Pattern of what I must do all my Life time after to morrow.

sp.speaker: Frien.
sp.p: But what necessity is there, Madam, that both of you must be so heavily yoak'd? Can't you keep together in a fair Pasture, without a Clog about your Heels, or a Yoak about your Necks â€” 'Faith Madam, if you'd follow my Advice, you should take one anothers Words.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I doubt, Mr. Friendly, you would hardly put out 1000 l. without some other Security than the bare word of your Trustee; and though I dare trust all my dearest Concerns into the Hands of Mr. Fairlove, upon the Security of his Word; yet since it is customable for Form-sake, we will enterchangeably enter into the Bonds of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I see you are resolv'd, and that no Reasons nor Persuasions can change you. This Custom is a plaguy thing: There's no Remedy for Time out of mind; because our Fathers and Mothers, and great, great Grand-fathers and Grand-mothers wore those Bonds of Marriage, we must.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Prethee Friendly, leave off, did not you promise me you would say no more?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: 'Tis hard to see you on a Precipice, and not warn you of it â€” I'll say no more, here's my Hand on't; but I'll go with you, as one Friend does with another, that is, going to the Gallows, with a great deal of Grief and Compassion, to see you fairly Halter'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Madam Lucia, your Uncle and Aunt are returned from the Tavern; but so chirping and merry, their Eyes twincle, their Tongu â€¢ s run, and their Faces shine, that you would scarce think them the same turbulent, noysom Creatures they use to be.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This Furnish has spoil'd my Design. But 'tis my Admiration by what Charm he could unite them so lovingly.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Oh you know not the Charms of Wine, as they can make the greatest Friends fall out; so they can reconcile the stubbornest Foes, Man and Wife.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I must set them ag â€¢ in at Odds, or I shan't work my Intention â€” I know how to do it.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Prethee let us be gone, I would not see these Hobgoblins.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, Mr. Friendly, you shall bear Mr. Fairlove Company a whileâ€”Pollun, light them into that Parlor, a while, it shall not be long e're I wait on you again. Exeunt Pollux lighting in Fairlove and Friendly.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Madam Lucia, your humble Servant â€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Grin Sneak, your Servant â€” what a foot still, and in Old Cloaths? Do none of your Projects hit yet? Where stick they, Mr. Sneak? â€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Well Madam, we shall be happy at last â€” I'm in a fair wayâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To Beggery. Aside

But Mr. Sneak, I have met with a man, that has been this forty
eight years studying a rare Project, and indeed, one that will be beneficial to all Curious Persons; and especially to Travellers; and he tells me, that now at last he has attained it; and that he shall have perfected his Design by that time the Patent can be got for it.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, what is this rare Invention you speak of?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, the Invention is extraordinary, it is a pair of Wings to fly into the Moon.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Why, that is not possible.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How unreasonable you are now, not to believe another, and yet impose as impossible things on the Faith of others? And to tell you very freely, Mr. Sneak, my thoughts are, 'twill be sooner effected than most of those things you dream of: For you cannot but know, that Dedalus and Icarus could fly half way to the Moon; and of several others, that could fly from high Towers, like Kites, or Eagles.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Indeed, it would be an admirable way of Travelling; I'll speak to my Lady Medler about the Patent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis good to speak in time: It will be of extraordinary Benefit to you; and I hope, worth the Vertuoso's while, labor and pains. He has studied all the Mathematicks, and run thorow the Philosophy of Atoms, of Weight and Gravity; weighed all sorts of Air, and lain whole days on his Back, to observe the Motions of Kites, Swallows, Doves, Batts, and Butterflies, making Comments and Observations on their several Motions; and now at last Mr. Sneak, this Flying Man, having brought his Wings to perfection, intends to visit the Moon shortly.

sp.speaker: Se.
sp.p: Let me advise him to get a Patent before he goes, and to communicate his Art to one, least he should miscarry: For I look upon the Voyage far more dangerous than that of Columbus, when he went in ursuit of the other World.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: As to the last, I may perhaps get him to communicate it to you: For he is almost afraid to own it after all, least he should be knock'd on the Head, by the Coachmen, Watermen and Seamen: For 'twill spoil their Trade. Besides, some have persuaded the Husband-men, that there will (if this Project goes forward) be such Clouds of Flying People in the Air, that 'twill hinder the Sun from ripening their Corn: So that he is afraid he shall be kill'd by them for the Invention; and he must be upon the Wing, out of the reach of shot, or in the Moon to secure himself.
Oh here's your Friend my Lady Medler! I'll leave you to discourse your Affairsâ€” Sneak turns about, and pulling his Handkerchief out of his Pocket, drops a Paper, which Lucia takes up â€” Exit.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p:
I have run all over the Town to look you out; I wonder what you do here, when you have so many grand Concerns on foot. I assure you, Mr. Sneak, if you will not be more quick and brisk
in the Business, I shall leave you, and all your Patents together; and then see what you will make of 'em.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: O Pray Madam, be not angry, I was engaged in a very grand Design, one of the best Projects I ever yet met with, very feasible and extreamly beneficial, which I will communicate to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: But Mr. Sneak, I have met with a Project this day, so extraordinary, and so exceeding beneficial, both to us, and to the whole Kingdom, that I hug my self, to have been so happy as to hear the first Proposition of it, from the Vertuoso himself â€” I will take you in for a Share, Mr. Sneak, we will make one another happy â€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Madam, you honour your Servant, pray what is it?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Why, there is a person come to Town, that was with me this day, that proposes to build a Fleet of Sheeps all of Portland Stone, to save the Woods which begin to grow thin, and Timber scarce; and he will undertake to build them so thick, that no Bullet shall pierce them. Then we shall have Castles indeed floating on the Seas, as a modern Poet says.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Sure that is not feasible, which way can he do it; he must sheath them all with Cork sure?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Nay, which way he does it, is a Secret; but he has brought it to Demonstration already by a little one, the very Yards and Masts are all of Stone too.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: But the Tackle and Sales are not made of Stone too, I hope.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: No â€” but they are not of Hemp nor Canvass.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Because we may not be beholden to Forreign Nations, and to promote the Growth of our own Nation, all the Sales are made of Tinn, and the Shrouds, Tackle and Cables of twisted Wires. What need we then care for Denmark or Norway?

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: 'Tis admirable; and if he can but convince me by Demonstration, I shall look upon it as the most happy thing I ever light on. I beseech you, Madam, promote it for the Good of the Nation.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I intend it, I assure you, I am this Night to give the Gentleman a meeting about it: You shall go with me in my Coach; and as we go, you shall communicate to me the happy Project you have met with this day. Come in with me, I will but speak two words to Mr. Turbulent, and we'll go. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What have I got here â€” something that dropt from Mr. Sneak; I must see what 'tis â€” Reads
sp.stage: An Account of my Estate in Posse
sp.p: Very good! I shall see how rich this Gentleman is in Posse, when I'm sure he has not any thing in Esse.
Imprimis, My Share in the Flax-Business, at 20 l. per Week 1000 l. a Year.

Item, My Concerns in my Black Box, being several Bonds, Mortgages,
Defeasances, and Statute-Staples, worth 20000 l.
Item, For procuring the Patent for the Consulship of Marselles 200 l.
Item, When the M â€¢ tch is made between my Lord Muchland's Son, and Justice Gripewell's Grand-child â€” 1000 l.

'Tis too long to read â€” Oh, here he is come to look his Paperâ€” I'll see the Summa totalis â€” 200000 l. a very fair Estateâ€”This man is fit for Bedlam: I must do him the kindness to send him thither with my Uncle, that he may be cur'd.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Oh Madam, I think that's the Paper I was looking for; I would not have lost it for any thing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Sneak, it does but let us know how rich you are â€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: No Madam, how rich I am like to be â€” And if Fortune does not oppose too much, I am like to be competently happy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Here Sirâ€” [Gives him his Paper] I think you are happy already, that can content your self with an Estate in Posse, whilst there is nothing but Air in your Pockets. I doubt, your Old Bills and Lands, and all your new Projects will come to little â€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I cannot stay now Madam, to convince you, my Lady Medler stays for me; or else I'd let you understand, that I do not take false measures â€” Madam, your humble Servant. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Thou art the confidentest Projecting Fool, that ever I met with, whom neither being baffled, laughed at, gull'd and cheated, can convince; whom the Counter, Kings-Bench, Want, nor Misery, can convert, or make feasible. There is but one Refuge left for thee, and that is Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Mr. Furnish is come fitted to all purposes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That's well, where's my Uncle?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Lain down to take a Nap â€” he has been a sleep a good while â€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Go you to my Cousin Furnish, tell him, I'll be with him presently. I'll speak but two words to Mr. Fairlove, and I'll follow you. Exeunt severally.
sp.stage: Enter Mr. Turbulent, with his Cap on.
sp.p: So, I have settled my Head with this Nap; my Stomach begins to crave Victualsâ€” I am grieved, that Mr. Sly, and his Wife should give such Occasion of Scandal to the Wicked â€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Did you call Sir?â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Yes Sirrah. Where's the Mistress?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Gone to her Singing-Meeting, in Sun-dial-Alley.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Where is Priscilla?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Gone to visit one of her Brothers hard by; she said she would not stay â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p:
Set me the Candle, and the Box of Books: I will read till
they return â€” Candle, and black Box set by him, and Table.
So Paul, get me ready half a dozen Turky Eggs for my Supper â€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I shall Sir â€” I doubt you won't stay to eat 'em Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O Uncle, Uncle. we are undone for ever: For God's sake hide your self streight, or you'll be taken.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: (Starts up, and looks frighted) What's the matter Luciaâ€” why do you fright me thus?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Fright you? why, the Parlor below is full of Souldiers, they are come to have you away to Prisonâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh sad Timesâ€” What Times do we live in, that a man cannot be quiet in his House, which is his Castle, what have I done?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, no expostulating nowâ€” you have been letting your Tongue run at London, and talk'd Treason: They say too, one Mr. Pricket is a meer Informer, and will witness against you.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: O wicked and abominable Age â€” O base Impostor, Vile Varlet, Hypocrite, Wretch â€” Lucy, what shall I do? â€” I shall be undone if I'm taken â€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Oh Sir, hide, hide your self, here are I know not how many Souldiers, Red-Coats, and an Officer to search for you: they are just coming up Stairs.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Now is your time to make use of your Armor. Come, come away, put your self into the Posture, and avoid being taken.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Come good Lucy, help me, I tremble, I know not what to do â€” Paul, Go down and divert them a little: Say I an abroad, any thing â€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I shall do my endeavor â€” Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, let us in quickly â€” I hear 'em coming. This comes of talking against the Times, with those you know not â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh I hear them coming â€” Oh, what shall I do? â€”

div.stage: Enter Furnish, Hangby, and others, with Red Coats, like Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Where is this Traytorâ€” Where is this Mr. Turbulent, that is troubling every Body; and still railing against the Times? â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: As good Drinking, Whoreing, Cheating Times, as any ever were since the Creation â€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: So, he is gone to hide â€” you have put him into a monstrous Fright â€” I find he would be no good Martyr for the Cause â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: These troublesome talking men are usually great Cowards.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: what have I got here, a Box of Writings? Takes up the black Box.
I hope I have light on the Judgment I confess'd to him for 500 l. If it be, I am very lucky â€” (opens the Box) P â€¢ haw â€” nothing but a Company of paltry Books â€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: They are my Masters choicest Library, I'll assure you, and things of great Value and Esteem with him â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Hang 'em Pamphlets â€” Flings them by.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Let's see 'em, a man may as well be known by the Books he converses with, as by the Company he keeps â€” Looks them over, and reads â€”
Lilly's Prophesies.
Merlin's Prophesies.
Mother Shipton's Prophesies.
Dabritius his Prophesies.
Arise Evans, and the Maid of Kent's Prophesies.
Hannah Trapnel's Visions.
Theaura John, and motive Motions, Visions.
Sir John Wroth's Visions.
Prin against Plays, Cards and Dice.
The Holy Lives of Knipper Dolling, and John of Leyden.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Excellent Books â€” a rare Collection â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Here be more â€” the second part to the same Tune.
Muggleton's Aphorisms.
The Ranters Religion. And
John Taylor's Holy Balade.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Most choice things â€” No Wonder that he is mad when he studies these â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: And rail against the Times â€” meddle with Government.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Perverting the Foolish, provoking the Froward, and spitting forth his Gall and Venom which he sucks from these Weeds.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Which feeds the foolish Hopes, and idle Fancies of such Lunatick Brains.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Who call every vain Dream a Prophecy, and every idle Chymical Fancy a Vision â€” Good Pollux, fling these Books into the Fire; 'twell be a very great Inducement towards my Uncle's Cure â€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, my Uncle is hid; but you may find him in the Press, in a little Room within his Chamber, he is sufficiently frighted â€” He says Mr. Pricket is a wicked man â€” You know the way Cousin Furnishâ€” Fright him as much as you will; but do not touch him â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Noâ€”noâ€” we won't hurt him â€” Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Luc. Pollux.
sp.p: Go you to Mr. Fairlove and Mr. Friendly, and bring them to us â€” Fairlove shall see my Uncle Turbulent in Disguise â€”

div.stage: A Press discovered. Enter Furnish, Hangby, Souldiers, after them Lucia.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Where is this Traytor? â€” He must be about the House â€” I'll leave no Corner unsearch'd â€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You see he is not here â€” won't you be satisfied?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Come let's see what's in this Press â€” open it, where's the Key â€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There's nothing there I'll assure you but a Statue.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Open it, or wee'll break it open â€” I must and will see what's in it â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: There may be Arms hid there for ought we know â€”
Lucia opens the Press, Mr. Turbulent discovered in it, standing bolt upright, armed Cap a pe, all of Brown Paper, with a Truncheon in his Hand; he stands without any Motion, imitating a Statue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Look you there, to satisfie you, here is nothing, but a meer Statue of my Uncle's, that was sent him for a Present.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What have we here, â€” a Jack in a Box?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Bevis of Southampton.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis John of Gaunt â€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No Sir, 'tis John of Leyden, as he march'd before his Anabaptistical Army.

div.stage: Enter Pollux, Mr. Fairlove, and Friendly.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Look you Sir, there stands my Master Mr. Turbulent in his Posture, in a Suit of Arms of his own making: Does not he look much like a General?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Prethee tell me Friendly, can'st forbear laughing now?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I confess this is extraordinary, and I will as soon give two pence to see this, as e're a Monster, or strange Sight in Bartholomew Fair â€”Is it possible this Fellow should have so little Sence in him.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: How still he stands! he is fast frozen with Fear.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: This is a meer Teraphim, and this Mr. Turbulent a meer Heathen Idolater â€” and here he keeps his great Idol in Secret â€” I shall inform of this, and have him burnt for a Pagan.â€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: No, no, you are mistaken, 'tis the direct Image of Oliver; he cannot be content to adore him in his Heart; but he sets up his Image in his Press, and in his Chamber.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Indeed Sir you are mistaken, he never lov'd Oliver in his life, nor any Governor, nor Governmentâ€” you do him a great deal of wrong: He was then the same Mr. Turbulent that he is now â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I know he is a very turbulent, troublesome fellow; but I did not think, that he, who was still railing against Images and Idolatry, should have them thus privately lock'd up in Presses, like those in Westminster Abby; but let it be whose Image it will, I'll shoot it.

div.stage: Presents a Pistol, the Image shakes, and lets fall the Truncheon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What do you mean Sir? Oh forbear Sir, 'tis a meer Image, a very harmless Statue, Sir, what, shoot a Statue?â€”Oh good Sir, by no meansâ€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Look, look, the Statue shakes, and has let fall his Truncheonâ€” 'tis a piece of Witchcraft â€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing but the shaking of the Press, that does not stand fastâ€”

div.stage: She shuts the Press (Aside to Mr. Turbulent) You had like to have spoil'd allâ€”stand stillâ€”You see Gentlemen, Mr. Turbulent is not in the Houseâ€” Pray Gentlemen, now are satisfied, leave us to our selves â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: We shall meet with him sometime or other, and he shall pay dearly for all his Treasonable Speeches, and for his Idol of John of Leyden too â€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, you have frighted him sufficientlyâ€”I am afraid he'll spoil his Armor behind â€”

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: This has done me as much good as the 50 l. I have got of him to day â€” Come Hangbyâ€” Exeunt. Furnish, Hangby, and Souldiers,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mr. Fairlove, If you will walk down, I will wait on you instantly. Pollux and I must uncase my Uncle first, and deliver him out of the Fright we have put him in â€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: He owes you much for his Deliverance.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: She has made him Mr. Peacable instead of Mr. Turbulent.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Oh, he never talks in Armorâ€” Exeunt Fairlove Friendly.

div.stage: Lucia opens the Press, and Mr. Turbulent putting up the Visor of his Helmet, comes forth upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I Protest, your Fear had like t'have spoil'd all â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: (Shaking) Are they gone? Are you sure they are gone?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes Sir, they are gone, and I have shut the Doors after them â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh, these are abominable Times, Oh, wicked and accursed Ageâ€”Oh, that I should live in such Times, that a man must be afraid to speak. Wicked Varlets, they'll go and inform I am an Heathen Idolater: What if they should come again? How should I escape? O the sight of the Pistol has put me into such a Fright â€” See Neece, is not my Armor spoiled behind? I have been something leakyâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, no, all's wellâ€” 'Tis Proof enough against such Shot.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Shall I get your Supper ready Sir?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh these Rogues have frighted away my Stomach. The sight of the Devil is not so terrible to me as those Red Cloaths, with the Infernal Weapons of Muskets and Pistolsâ€” But Neece, what shall I do if they should come again? â€” I am afraid they will be here again to morrow â€”Oh! I dread a Prison, and to be confined within Wallsâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There is no better way for you, than to feign your self mad Pollux, and I will keep your Council, and then you may say any thing, which will be an ease to your Spirit; and you may do what you will, they will then only pity you, and take all to be an effect of your Madness; and that which you said likewise to Mr. Pricket â€” Madness you know excuses many things.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p:
Mad say you? â€” I need not counterfeit that, I am almost
mad already, to see the Wickedness and Profaneness of the Age, the Vileness and Lewdness of the Times, the Filthiness and Debauchery of this City, and the Ungodliness and Irreligion of the whole Nation.â€” I say, I can be very easily mad; and I will be so to save my self, and to avoid being taken in the Snare of the Wicked Red-coatsâ€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You had best make Tryal Sir, how you can deceive my Old Mistress and my Young Mistressâ€” if you can deceive them handsomly, then you may be confident you may deceive any body elseâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh Sir, here is Doctor Quibus, practice first upon him â€” now try what you can do â€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
I'll leave you here to keep them asunder; I must go to Mr. Fairlove
Exit Lucia.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Vat de Debil is dis? Mr. Turbulent in Armor? I come to see my Patient: Is dis he in dis Case? morblewâ€” Vat art dow?â€” speakâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I am Mars the God of Warâ€”I am Mars, I tell thee; and I will slay thee Pigmy. Lays hold on his Sword.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I am afraid Sir, my Master is a little besides himselfâ€” he does not use to talk thus.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Ay, de Color is got into de Brain, and has turn'd de Brain vith de hot Fumesâ€” He take de Physic in the Morn, he take de Caudle at de Noon, he go to de Meeting in de Afternoon, and to de Tabern at de Night; all dis is enough to make de vel man man stark madâ€”He must have de Ellebore, de strong Purge of de Ellebore, and de spare Diet, and be kept dark, dat he may be cured.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Thou art an Ass Doctor, and understandest not any thingâ€” Mars never eat Helleboreâ€” You are no Son of Apollo; you are not Aesculapius, I know him by his Beardâ€” Thou art an Elf, born in Fairy Land, and hast failed hither in an Egg-shell, to poyson the Nation with Rats-bain and Dogs Turds: But I tell thee, I am Mars, and I will slay thee. Lays hold on his Sword, Pollux stops him.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: De debil go vit deeâ€”I will stay no longerâ€” de vine is in his Brainâ€” Go, go to de Sleep, and settle de Brain; or else to de Bedlam, dat is de fittest place for deeâ€” Exit.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: So, did I not do well? â€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes Sir admirably â€” admirably wellâ€” 'tis natural to youâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Come, help me off with my Armsâ€” Let us go inâ€” and go, and get my Eggs ready â€” I am almost faint with Fasting.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But you must remember to be mad again when you see my Mistressâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, let me alone. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fair. Will.
sp.p: Friendly (like the Philosopher that never laugh'd till he saw an Ass eating Thistles, nabbing and pricking his Lips) could not chuse but smile a little, when he saw your Uncle in his posture.

sp.speaker: Luc.
