sp.p: You would hardly have believ'd this, had not your eyes been Witnessesâ€” I assure you this Suit of Armor was an Invention of his own Brain, as well as the Work of his own hands.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I confess, 'twas something surprizing, and might prove Diversion enough for those that love to make themselves sport with the folly of others â€” but I pity himâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ne'r pity him, 'tis his Nature; and you may as well pity a Swine for grunting, or a Dog for barkingâ€” you were no sooner gone, and that we had releas'd him from his Fear; but he return'd to his old wont of railing against the Times.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible to convert him from that

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have but one way to do itâ€”and I'll make a Tryal of itâ€” Well, I'll dismiss you till to morrowâ€” and thenâ€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I will release you from your Slavery.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: And with a Habeas Corpus remove her from one Prison to another.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That is as it may happen.

div.stage: Enter Cringe, Singing Fa la la la.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Away Fairloveâ€” here is the foolish City Poet: I had rather meet a Ghost, than this troublesome Fopâ€” you shall have enough of your Mistress to morrowâ€” Exit, pulling Fairlove with him.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Mrs. Lucia, are you still in the same mind you were in last time I saw you, hey?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes indeed am I Sir; and therefore let me not hear one word more either of Love or Verses: For I hate them both, especially from you.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Now did you think I would go hang or drown my self, hey? â€” Fa, la, la, la, fa, la, la, la â€” Now are you deceiv'd: I won't so much as write an Elegy on our parting, hey? â€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I care not what you do with your self so you trouble not me.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: You shall see, I know what belongs to the fathomable Love of our Times hey? â€” Fa la la la â€” I'll love you no longer than you love Mr. Fa la la la â€” Pshaw, 'twas only my Diversion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'm glad Mr. Cringe, you and I so well agree at parting â€” But are you provided of another Love? That's fashionable too: You ought to have another Miss or twoâ€”what says my Cousin Priscilla?

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: She is not such a Fool as you are; she knows when she is well profer'd: and look youâ€” hey, to vex you heyâ€” see I have [pulling out Parchment] scratch'd your Name out of the Licence, and put in Mrs. Priscilla's: Do you see that, hey? â€” Fal la la, Fal la la laâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is a pleasant Loverâ€” Oh my Auntâ€”
Oh Aunt, here has befell us a most sad Disaster since your went.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Here have been Soulders to search for my Uncle, which made
him fly into his Brown Paper Arms, his last Refugeâ€”But what with the Fear they put him in, the Wine he has drunk at the Tavern, and his chollerick melancholly Distemper, as Doctor Quibus calls it, he is quite besides himself, and out of his Witsâ€” The House can hardly hold him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: O the sad and deplorable Times that we live in, there have not been such lewd, wicked Times since Adam â€” They talk of the Iron Age; I tell you this is a Flinty Age, or a meer stony, rocky, adamantive Age, that they cannot let a poor man be in quiet in his own house â€”O sadâ€”sadâ€”sad Timesâ€” Oh Neece, these are abominable Times, and we are governed by the Nebuchadnezzars and Balshazzars of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Now have I put her into a Fit of Railing: But Aunt, Doctor Quibus has been to see him, and he is so raging mad, that he had like to have beat the Doctor; he says, he's absolutely distracted as any in Bedlam, and advises you, by all means, to put him in there to be curedâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I can't believe itâ€” 'tis but a Fitâ€” he'll be well againâ€” Oh these Timesâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What agen?â€”Good Aunt let the Times alone, and consider what you have to doâ€” Lookâ€” Enter Priscilla. Here is my Cousin Priscillaâ€”take her Advice.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: What is the Subject of your Discourse, is it proper or common?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: The Subject is very proper: your Father is mad they say; and the Question is, what shall we do with him? He is raging, and he will be too hot for the House, and too troublesome to us all.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Canst thou prove it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, without a Syllogismâ€”if you go to him, he will demonstrate itâ€”

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: He is then in an evil predicamentâ€” for if he hath lost his Reason, plainly he is a Brute.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And therefore I would have your Mother provide for him a little Chamber in the Hospital over the way, till his Reason and his Knowledge return again to him: and where proper Physick, and fit Dyet may be administred to himâ€”

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: 'Tis true, his Reason may be actually lost for a time; but it may be still in Potentia, and may be recovered.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter with Mr. Turbulent hey? He is mad sure, hey? â€” I went to him about some earnest business, and he flew at me like a Dragon; If it had not been for honest Paul, he would have murthered me, hey â€” what ails he? heyâ€” how came he so? heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He's troubled with Melancholly Mr. Cringe, he is in a cholerick melancholly Fitâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: A cholerick fit indeed heyâ€” I don't love to see such cholerick Fits heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You are troubled with Melancholly too Mr. Cringe.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Who I? hah, hah, heyâ€” who I? Fa la la la laâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes you Mr. Cringe, for all your fa la la laâ€” You are troubled with the laughing Melancholly, the rhiming, versifying Melancholy, the singing, light airy fa la Melancholly â€” Indeed you are far gone, and have need of Cure, Mr. Cringe, I advise for the best.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Mistress Priscilla, she says, this out of mere spite, because I have left herâ€” Look here, I have put you into the Licence, and I'll marry you to morrow, heyâ€”what say you hey? Here's my Hand heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: I say, that this Proposition may be in the Mode Puerpera, that is the possible Mode; or it may be Edentuli, the necessary Modeâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: And I'll go study an Epithalamium against to morrow, heyâ€” Fa la la la la la. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I advise you Cousin, to lay by your Modes and your Figures, and take Mr. Cringe while he is in in the Mood: you'll never get such a Husbandâ€”Come, I'll see it done to morrow my self â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: If Mr. Turbulent be mad, he is under Tribulation: He is chastized for going to the profane House called a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You must now place your self Aunt, at the Helm of Government in your Family, and compell my Uncle, for his own good, to enter into Bedlam, and to be under Confinement, and subject to Government, which he always abhorr'dâ€” O here is another of the Melanchollicks, Enter Suckthumb.
And the fittest person in the World to bear my Uncle Companyâ€” 'Tis pity they should be parted, this is the Eye, and my Uncle the Tongue of Seditionâ€”

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Where is Brother Turbulent? â€” I am returned from Brother Sly and Sister Sly, who are put into Tribulation, and are entred into the Prison called the Round-house, sent thither by the Earthly Justice, Right-or-wrongâ€” I come to condole with Brother Turbulent about this matter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Alas Brother Abednego, Mr. Turbulent has lost his Reason.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Then he is purifiedâ€” he ought not to have any thing to do with Reasonâ€” It is the Idol of the World, and the very Babel of the Sons of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Do'st thou speak against Reason and Logic? I doubt thou art ignorant, and canst not distinguish.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Logic is the very Language of Babel, and used by the carnal, and the profane men of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So this is good, they are going together by the Ears about Logic and Reason, which they neither understand any more than a Goose or a Sea-gull.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Thou speakest evilly of the best thing in the World: It is Reason only that distinguishes us from Beasts.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p:
I say Reason is the Filth and Scum of the Carnal Brain: It is the Sut and Fume of Hell: it ought to be banish'd, and not made
use of: it is the Froth of a corrupted mind: it is the Carnal Weapon of the wicked, learned men â€” And I say again, we ought to live above Reason, beyond Reason, and to Act against Reason, and contrary to Reason, and to pull down Reason, and to overthrow, overthrow, overthrowâ€” the Idol Reason.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Wilt thou give me leave to reply?

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Thou canst not, shalt not reply, nor take the part of Reasonâ€” 'Tis that which causes the Rulers of the Earth to impose Laws on us: 'tis that which causes the outward Worship, and the congregating in Stone Churches: 'tis that which causes the Orders and the Ceremonies, the Institutions, and the Schools, and the Universities, and the Study, and the Books and subtle Questions and Answers among the men of the Worldâ€”'Tis the very Root of all Evil, and it must be confounded; and if Brother Turbulent has lost his Reason, he is become perfect.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: I must tell thee Friend, thou lyest, Reason ought not to be lost, nor to be cast down, nor confounded.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I say it is lost, and shall be cast down, and shall be confounded.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: I say it shall not, and thou art a Beast without thy Reason.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I say it shall, and thou art a very Beast with thy Reason.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is pleasantâ€” two irrational Animals, to fall out about what neither of them haveâ€” but here comes one will end their Disputeâ€”

div.stage: Entet Mr. Turbulent in his Night Gown and Cap, staring like a mad man, his Hands bound behind him, and led in by Pollux.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Here they are, Mr. Suckthumb with 'em, now see if you can deceive 'em, and the Visioneer tooâ€” you may then deceive any bodyâ€” Now Master, act your part bravelyâ€”

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, let me alone to counterfeitâ€”

sp.speaker: Suckthumb.
sp.p: Brother Turbulent, I have now the Interpretation of the Vision, I had at our Meeting. The Eagle on the top of the Tree, was Brother Sly, the Tree was the Round-house where he is put; and the Dragon was that Dragon-like Justice Right-or-wrong, who hath devoured himâ€”

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: What sayest thou? Didst thou name the Dragon? hahâ€” art thou Bell? hahâ€”

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Do'st thou see a Vision?

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: Yes I see thee, the Gyant Gogmagog, that devourest the Peopleâ€” but I will encounter thee, and cast thee to the Earth.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Peace, he prophesiethâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Tim. I am sorry to see thee distracted. Do'st thou know me thy own Wife? â€” I am afraid to go near him, he stares soâ€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You need not fear him: See I have bound his Hands â€” he can't hurt you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Why do'st not speak to me Tim.? â€” They were vile Varlets, to afright the out of thy Sencesâ€”

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: Avaunt, thou art a Succubus, a Shee Devil; and from thy Womb proceeds the Spawn of Antichrist: Thou art the Whore of Babylon, and I will overthrow theeâ€” Runs towards her, Pol. holds him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Oh vile and abominable man. Ay, ay, I see he is mad now, to abuse his own dear Wife.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Peace, Peace, he speaketh wonderful things, and high Mysteries He is in a Rapture, Sister Turbulent, he meaneth not thy carnal Womb, he meaneth Spiritually â€” Hearken, I pray, with Attention â€” These are Mysteriesâ€” and Raptures â€”

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: May I put thee a plain Proposition?â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Thou art a She Crocodile, and feedest upon Croaking Frogsâ€” nothing but dark Fumes passeth from thy Throat, and thy words are as the sounding of empty Tubbs â€” I will tear up thy Idols, and cast them into the Fire, and burn thy Molock Logick-Books as a Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Nay plainly, I see he is now distracted, he hath quite lost his Reason.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I say he speaketh great things, and they ought to be written in Brass, with a Pen of Steel â€” They are high Prophesies, and the Interpretation may be givenâ€” Call not thy Father madâ€” He is become perfect, and has laid aside his Reason, the Ensign of his Carnallity.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: Oh the roaring of the Lions, and the howling of the Wolves, the Neighing of Horses, and the beating of Drums, heark the noise of the Canons, and the dashing of Rocks together â€” Heark again, the bellowing of Bulls, and the braying of Asses; there is a Battel between the Beasts of the Earth, and the Fowls of the Air.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: These are wonderful thingsâ€” Oh he seeth strange Sights!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Tim. Tim. thou art madâ€”I will seek a Cure for thee.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Thou shalt have some Physick that thou mayest regain thy reason, which thou mayest yet have in Potentia.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He counterfeits bravelyâ€”.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: Hah hah hah! Come, you are all my Friends. I did but counterfeit, to see if I could deceive youâ€” I must do this when the Souldiers come, that they may think I'm madâ€” Did not I do it bravely? â€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Have a care Auntâ€” this is but a light Interval, as most mad people haveâ€” Come not near him, he is spitefulâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: No Tim. you do not use to counterfeitâ€” I'm sure you would not abuse your own Wife, if you had not been mad.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Dost thou own thy self a Counterfeit and a Deceiver? Nay, then we ought to shun thee. If thou art mad, we ought to run from thee, that thou mayest not hurt us: If thou art not mad, thou art then a Counterfeit and a Deceiver, and we ought not to keep thee Company. There is a Dilemma for theeâ€” thou hast brought thy self plainly into this Dilemma.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: Here Wife, untie my Hands that I may beat that Baggage: I'll teach her better Manners, you Quaking, Impudent Jilflirtâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I see Tim. you are falling again into a Fit, I see by the Roll of your Eyesâ€”

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: O you vile woman, won't you believe me? â€”
sp.stage: Offers to run at her, with-held by Pollux.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Thou art returning into thy Raptureâ€”

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: Rapture? You Fool, you Idiot, I tell thee I did but counterfeitâ€”Unloose meâ€”these wicked Women will take the Helm of Government out of my hand elseâ€”

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Brother, I am sorry thou should'st say, thou didst counterfeit, that is the greatest Sign I have yet seen of thy madnessâ€” be reconciled to thy self, and own thy Raptures.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: I have made a fair hand on't, and counterfeited so well they won't believe me: I say, Brother unloose these Bands â€”

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I dare not, if they were imposed on thee by the Legal Authority of thy Wife, or her Lawful Ministers: Let them be loosed by the same Authority, I shall not meddle with them; but I can suffer with thee, and will not leave thee in thy Affliction.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: A company of Rogues, Whores, Varlets, I'll teach you all to abuse me thus. Offers in great rage to fall on them, is held by Pollux and Lucy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Away Auntâ€” he's in another raging Fit, quickly, quickly away, come awayâ€” Mrs. Turbulent and Pris. run out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Nay, I see he is mad indeed nowâ€”

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: He hath lost his Reasonâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Come Neece, undo my Handsâ€”I have counterfeited so long, they won't believe me nowâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed Uncle, you do it very naturally, now you counterfeit your self soberâ€” but you are mad stillâ€” (Whispers) Uncle, shall I have my Portion, and marry Mr. Fairlove?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: O I could tear you to pieces, you vile Wretch, you abominable Baggageâ€” I'll eat thee upâ€” â€¢ hat I will. Do you mock me, and sport your self with me? â€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I thought that would put him into a Rage again. So Uncle, you are fallen into another Fit.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I will not leave him, I will stay with him till his Zeal is abated.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Sirrah Pollux, undo my Hands that I may beat them all into their right Sences.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Well Uncle, I'll leave you, and consult with my Aunt about your Cureâ€” Be sure you keep him fast Pol.
Whispers to Pol.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Ne'r fearâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Uncle, you had best go sleep, and settle your Brain, 'tis lateâ€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Come Sir, she advises well: will you see if you can rest? The Chollerick Fumes trouble your Brain.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Sirrah leave prateingâ€” I'll jest no longer: untie my hands I sayâ€” I'll make 'em know me. Do they rebell against their Head?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, I dare not, Do you think I am wiser than my Old Mrs. and my young Mrs. and Mrs. Lucyâ€” I should be madder than you, if I should untie your hands â€” They have order'd to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: Theyâ€”theyâ€”theyâ€” they order?â€” this is fine; Oh I will be reveng'd on them for this.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Possess your self with patienceâ€” I will assist thee, and we will speak to Sister Kate once moreâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Speak-patience say you? I'll after them, and tear them to pieces with my Teeth, vile, abominable, wretched, wicked, stinking, filthy Womenâ€” Runs out.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: He is again fallen into a Raptureâ€” I will follow and see the end of these things. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: So â€” There will be something to do among 'em.

q.l: These sort of men, your Holy Melanchollicks,
Thus cheat each other with Religious Frolicks.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: The Fifth Act. The Scene Bethlem.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: INdeed this is a fine placeâ€” the fairest Hospital I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Better than that of the Incurable of Venice; 'tis much for the Honor of the City, Madam: But did you never see it before, Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Noâ€” nor had not now, had it not been to see my Friend Mr. Turbulentâ€” The Sight of Bethlem, the Tombs, and the Lions are no Recreation for Ladies of Quality.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: 'Tis strange Mr. Turbulent should so soon become mad.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Indeed I had some Jealousie of it the last time I saw him: For he told me I look'd Oldish. I thought indeed he was a little crack'd, to tell me I look'd Oldâ€” out upon himâ€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Why Madam, is that such a Fault, Age is Honourable, and every body desirous to live till they are Old: why then should Old Age be so despicable?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Age is Honourable! marry come upâ€” I say Age is not honourableâ€” nor you for saying soâ€” It is an old musty Adage; and I say Age is good for nothing, but to spoil good Faces, brisk Wits, and active Bodies; to bring Wrinkles, gray Hairs, moist Eyes, slavering Lips, Aches in the Joynts, and Gouts in the Limbsâ€” Age I say, is a most wicked and an abominable thingâ€” and to tax me with it?â€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Nay Madam, that indeed was a Crime.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Had he call'd me Whore, or Bawd, or Cheat or so, it had not vex'd me half so much â€” but poor man, he was out of his Sencesâ€”

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Monsieur Sneak, you be velcom to de Betlem; here is Monsieur Turbulent, and Monsieur Sucktum come here to be cured of do Melancholick, and you be come also in de very good timeâ€” you do very much vant de Ellebore.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I am well enough Doctor, I am not melancholly.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: You be de very melancholly man in de World â€” It is de melancholly dat trobles your Brain, dat makes you run here, run dere all day long, all de veek, all de year, after de project, and get noting, not one straw, you'll be de true melancholly Pick-straw.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Madam, this Doctor is like most of the World, they will not believe, till they see me in my Coach and six Horsesâ€” Well Doctor, I shall convince you shortlyâ€” I will build an Hospital shall far exceed thisâ€”

sp.speaker: Dr. Que.
sp.p: Ay, dat is in de Brainâ€” dere is one of de Wind-mills dat goes vur, vur, vurâ€” dat is ven de project comes to perfection. I tell you Monsieur Sneak, vat you shall do vith your Money, you shall build tree such Hospitals, one on each side of dis Square, and den dere will be four, one for each sort of de Melancholly: dis vil hardly hold half de melancholly Pick-straws in dis Town.

sp.speaker: Sne
sp.p: You are a jeering Doctorâ€”

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Is there not one Mr. Turbulent here?

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: Yes, he is above in the upper Galleryâ€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Now you are here. Madam, by all means see the mad folksâ€” the Keeper will let you see themâ€”

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: Yes, you may see them if you please?â€”

div.stage: The Scene is drawn open, and discovers several sorts of mad People.

sp.speaker: Lad. Med.
sp.p: Do you let them walk about looseâ€”

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: Such as are harmless, and that are not raving, are permitted to walk here in this Gallery.

div.stage: Enter on the Stage a young Maid antickly dress'd, staring and singing.

sp.speaker: Mad maid.

q.l: Tell me prethee faithless swain,
Tell me prethee faithless swain,
Why you did such passion feign,
On purpose to deceive me?
I no sooner lov'd again.

sp.p: But you began to leave me â€” Hey hoeâ€”Are you Strephon? â€” No, no, you are not he; he had Garlands on his headâ€” (Singing) Oh my Love's dead, and laid in his watry Grave. Pray tell me, did you see Strephon? â€” (Singing)
Tell me gentle Strephon, why
You from my Embraces fly? Ohâ€” there he is, there he is, stay, stay, stay, Strephon, stay. Exit running.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Alas poor Maid.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: She is one that fell mad with Love.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dis is one of de melancholly Fa la's, and Monsieur Finical Cringe vould do very well to keep her company, he is de madder of de twoâ€”

div.stage: Walk over the Stake, one in a Gown and Cap, reading in a Book, and not looking off. Exit.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: This is a Scholar that has crack'd his Brain in reading Aristotleâ€” He is always poreing on a Book, but won't speak in a week together.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dat is one of de melancholly Dumbsads; he no talk, he noting but tink, tink, of de Philosophy, and de strange tings, till he has turned de Brain: He is de Brother to Monsieur Sucktumâ€”

div.stage: Enter mad man passing o're the Stage.

l.hi: I'll pull down Honor from the pale-fac'd Moon,
And break the Wheels of the all-circling Sun.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: This is a mad Poetâ€”he ran mad with making of Versesâ€” He speaks them Ex tempore half a day together, and makes Love to all that comes near him in Rhime.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dis is one of de melancholly Pick-straws, dere be a great many in de same degree of Madness, dat goes about de Streets, and trobles de people vith dere Rhimes, and dere Nonsence â€”

div.stage: Enter mad man with many Papers in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: So, the Marigold from Smirna â€” Cargo, Raisons, Currance, Wine, Almonds, Silks, value 10000 l. The James and John from Genua, Cargo 5000 l. â€” The William and Mary, from Lisbon, laden with Sugars and Wine â€” Cargo 30000 l. â€”

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: This is a crack'd Merchant, doubly crack'd, first in his Estate, by the Loss of a Ship or two taken by the Dutch, and afterwards in his Brainâ€” but he is continually reckoning up his several Cargoes, that he fancies his Ships bring him from all parts, and summing up the Effects, and his Gains, he imagines himself the richest Merchant in the City of London.

sp.speaker: L. Med.
sp.p: Alas! poor poor manâ€”

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: 'Fait he be no poor man, he be de rich man in de Imagination: He is one of de melancholly Pick-straws, and in de very same Degree of dis Shentilman, he tinks himself rich in de Project.

div.stage: Enter mad man holding his Head on one side, and learing off with his Hands.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Stand saide, good Folks, stand aside, least I hurt you; pray give wayâ€” I'll gore you else.â€” Exit, making motions with his Head, and holding it on one side, as if to get his Horns through the Door.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: This is a Citizen that became Horn-mad through Jealousie: He fancies that his Horns are so bigg, that he cannot carry them in the Gallery, and that they weigh down his Head, that he is fain to carry it on one side.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dis is one of de Hypocondraic melanchollicks.

div.stage: Enter two habited like Scholars, with Caps and Gownsâ€” disputingâ€”

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I think all Cuckolds are as mad as he, that would make their Invisible Horns known to to all the Worldâ€”but who are these Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Madam, they are two mad Critics, that when they get together, are continually disputing about the Poets, Ancient and Modern: one calls himself Aristotle, and the other thinks himself Julius Scaliger.

sp.speaker: 1 Mad man.
sp.p: I say Mr. Aristotle, that the Poets of our Age, have nothing of Wit in them, and all their Peieces are false Draughtsâ€” O the wise Sophocles, the wise Euripides, the Oracles of their Ageâ€”

sp.speaker: 2 Mad.
sp.p: I say the Baye's, and the Ninnies of this Age are far beyond them, and they know more than they did, and write better Senceâ€”

sp.speaker: 1 Mad.
sp.p: I say Aristotle thou lyestâ€” The Ancient Aristophanes, and the witty Menander, were the only Persons that understood Comedy among the Greeksâ€” Terrence had some Wit; but Shakespear, and Ben. Johnson were mere Oafs.

div.stage: Enter mad Woman, pulling Sneak by the Sleeve on one side.

sp.speaker: Mad Wo.
sp.p: Are you married? â€” Exit.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: What means she by that? â€” I believe she is in love with meâ€” Aside, brisking up himself.

sp.speaker: 2 Mad.
sp.p: I say Mr. Scaliger, you are a proud, malepert and impudent Critick, to find fault with the very Inspired Priests of the Muses; and I tell you, your Euripides, Sophocles, Aristophanes and Menander, and all the rest of them were mere Ideots to the Poets of our Age.

div.stage: Enter mad Woman, pulling Sneak aside.

sp.speaker: Mad. Wo.
sp.p: You are not matried, are you?â€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Why do you ask? â€” Noâ€”

sp.speaker: Mad Wo.
sp.p: Don't let the Keeper see meâ€” I an't madâ€” I have 10000 l. to my Portion, and 500 l. a year, which a rich Uncle keeps from me in Berkshire, and keeps me here, and makes People believe I am mad, only to keep my Esta â€¢ eâ€” I am no more mad than you areâ€”

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Sir, pray have a care of that Woman, she is mad, and sometimes very mischievousâ€” How came you loose? â€” Go inâ€”

sp.speaker: Mad Wo.
sp.p: Youâ€”See he won't let me tell youâ€” but heark youâ€” I'll marry you, if you can get me out. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: This was a happy coming hither. 'Tis so, the Keeper is afraid I should discover it, she speaks very rationallyâ€” This was a very lucky chanceâ€” a happy Discoveryâ€” Aside.

sp.speaker: 1 Mad.
sp.p: I say you are a dull, insipid, and ignorant Critick; and I say again, the Kings of your Poets, are no better than Punchenello's; they are ridiculous, and want Majesty.

sp.speaker: Mad. Wo.
sp.p: You'll marry me then, and get me out of this place?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Pray Sir have a care of her, I give you warning.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Who is she? â€”

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: A Stocking-mender's Daughter, that has run mad through Pride, and fancies she has 10000 l. to her Portion, and 500 l. a year, in Berkshireâ€”

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Do not disturb dem, dey are de fittest to talk togeder dat I know: She hate de long Vorm in her Brain, and he hate de great Maggot in his: She fancies, she hate de 10000 l. and he imagines, he hate de 100000 l. ven he has noting. Which is de madder den?

sp.speaker: Mad Wo.
sp.p: Be sure you keep my Councilâ€” Exit.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: And I will, and marry thee too, and get thy Estateâ€”hah this is a lucky hit â€” I'll deal well enough with her Uncle, by the help of my Lady Medlerâ€”

sp.speaker: 2 Mad.
sp.p: Thou art a very venemous, wicked and reproachful Critick.

sp.speaker: 1 Mad.
sp.p: Thou art a scurrilous, surly, chymical Critick.

sp.speaker: 1 Mad.
sp.p: Thou artâ€” Lifting up their Fists.

sp.speaker: 2 Mad.
sp.p: And thou artâ€”

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Hold, I'll end your Quarrel â€” I am so troubled with these mad Criticks, when they meet together: They always dispute till they fall together by the Ears.

div.stage: Parts them, and turns them out severally.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dere be many of dese Greek Wits about dis Town, dat deserve a place in dis Hospital; dey do noting but find de fault, and pick de hole in de Coat of de Poet, and de Wits: dey see de motes in de Sun, and de spots in de Moon, and de Stars: dey find de fault in de Lines, in de Verse, in de Vords, in de Plays, vitout de Sence, or de Vit, or de Reasonâ€” Begar dey be all mad, and fit for de Betlemâ€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Madam I am very happy to dayâ€” I have made a most rare Discovery â€” I'll tell you anon, you must assist me in itâ€” you shall have a Share Madamâ€” I would not for a thousand pound but I had come here to dayâ€”

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I am glad of the good Fortuneâ€”

div.stage: Enter out of his Cell a mad Man Chain'd, shaking his Chains, and roaringâ€”

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Pull down the Starsâ€” hah, blow Boreas blow, make the Seas meet, dash Rocks together, and put out the Sight of the Sun.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I'm afraid of himâ€”

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: You need not, he is fast chain'd.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p:
Cerberus, dost thou howl Cerberus? I'll cut off thy three Necks, and boyl 'em for that Lady's Supperâ€” Avaunt, thou she
Fury: I'll leap thee else like an Incubus â€” Tear 'em, tear 'em tear 'emâ€” Ratling his Chains.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Go, get you inâ€” This is a frantick, outragious mad man.

div.stage: Exit mad man into his Cell.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dis is one of de coloric Melanchollicks, dat is full of de rage, and de raving Fits, and is not as de Lunaticks, vith de lucid Intervals: Dis sort, and de hot Brain, like de vild Fireâ€” Here be all de sorts of de mad men, and de melanchollicks in de Varld, and here dey take de Physick, and have de Cure for deir Malady and Distemper in de Brain.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And now I am come to the nine and fortieth point, the downfal of the Whore of Babylon. Mark me, the Judgments of the terrible Approach of the falling into nothing, of the polluted and sinful World, shall be turned and converted to Confusion and Distress; and then, you shall behold the Crowns of the Earth, be tumbled on Heaps, and the Seas, and the Moon, shall vanish into Vaporâ€” but thenâ€” Exit.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: This is a Fifth Monarchy Preacher, who employs himself this way all day long.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: He speaks as soberly as most of dem, and as mush Sence.

div.stage: Enter mad Woman again, pulling Sneak aside.

sp.speaker: Mad Wo.
sp.p: Let me tell you another Secret â€” You will marry me? â€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Yesâ€”yesâ€”and get you out; but take no notice then,

sp.speaker: Mad Wo.
sp.p: Heark you in your Ear. She whispers in his Ear.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Pray have a care Sir, of that Womanâ€”

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, oh, oh. Cries out she bites him by the Ear.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: O Lord, Mr. Sneak, what all you? â€”

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I told you what would come of itâ€” Keeper runs and takes her off, and turns out the mad Woman, who Exit laughing.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I think Mr. Sneak, you were madder than she, to trust your Ear in her mouth.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Is this Mr. Grin Sneak the Projector?â€”

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Yes, this is Mr. Grin. Sneakâ€”poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I have an Order here to provide for youâ€” I am glad you are come. Pulling out a Paper.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Only to carry you to your Companions, till I provide a Chamber for youâ€” I have your Name here, Mr. Timothy Turbulent, Mr. Abednego Suckthumb, and Mr. Grin Sneak. Whistles.
Here, carry this mad Gentleman to Mr. Turbulent.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: What do you mean? â€” I an't madâ€”

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Sure he is not madâ€”

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Here is Dr. Quibus, that receives a Pension from the House, and assists in the Cure of the mad Folks: He knows sure, better than you Madam, who is mad, and who is not â€” I have his Hand for it, and an Order to provide for him.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui,
sp.p: He is de very mad man in de Vorld, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: The Doctor understands nothing, I tell you I am not mad and I won't go with you.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: There is none of all these mad men that are here, but will say as much as you do; they do not think themselves mad no mo â€¢ e than you do.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: He vere not mad if he did not tink himself soâ€”

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Have him away, I sayâ€”away with him. Exeunt carrying out Sneak between them, Keeper, men and Sneak.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Alas! poor manâ€” I'll go after himâ€”

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: I'll vait on you Madamâ€” Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Fairlove, Friendly, Cringe, Lucia, Priscilla.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Now do I think this the fittest place in the World to conclude a Wedding in: For since you have been so mad as to put on the Fetters of Marriage, this Hospital is fittest for your Entertainment. I have seen you so mad, as to be married; but I despair of seeing your Cureâ€” I doubt your Frenzy is for Life.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: It has cost me some pains and study, to get my Uncle Turbulent hither; and now I have made sure of Mr. Fairlove, and my Portion, I care not how soon he is releas'd.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Let him be cur'd first of his Turbulency. I doubt, all the Physick in London will hardly change his Natureâ€” He feeds upon Choler, and he chews Galls and Bitterness, as if they were Eringo's or Marchpane.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I think this Hospital is the fittest place in the World for all those sort of People; and if I were rich enough, I would add to its Revenue: For it is a great deal of pity, that these kind of mad men should walk about the Streets as they do.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why Mr. Cringeâ€” What are you musing? â€” You are melancholly.

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: Who I? Fa la la laâ€” I was only meditating upon an Epithalamium, which I intend to speak my self to my Bride at night; heyâ€”heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Trouble not thy Head with vain Songs, plainly, they will be disagreeing to me, and Mr. Goyle told me, Poetry was an unsanctified Vocation, and that all Poets and Players were hang'd up by the Tongues in Hellâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Mr. Goyle is a Lyar heyâ€” for slandering the Poets heyâ€” Those were only the little bawdy, rhimeing, lampooning Poets; not those that make Heroicks heyâ€” I tell you, you shall hear my Epithalamium heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Do'st thou say, my Priscilla is married to that vile rhimeng Fellow Cringe?â€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes forsoothâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: And has my Neece married Mr. Fairlove, and got her Portion out of the Chamberlan's Hands?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes indeed, 'tis sure enough â€” look you here, they are together.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Wellâ€” 'tis well my poor Husband is already distracted, else I'm sure, this very News would make him mad.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mr. Cringe, Speakâ€” speak to herâ€” goâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: We have committed Matrimony forsooth Motherâ€” Look you, I have taken Mrs. Priscilla for better and for worse, heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: You have taken her without my Consent, Mr. Cringe, and consequently without any Portion â€”

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for that hey: I know how to go to Law heyâ€” I married your Daughter upon a lawful Consideration hey, and I shall force you heyâ€”.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Force me, force me? you impudent Ballad-maker: will you force me â€” Oh what Times do we live in! Force meâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Aunt, I'm afraid they'll think you mad as well as my Uncle. It is not good to be loud in this place, least they provide a Chamber for you.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I have taken care of your Neece, and taken her off your handsâ€” I assure you, she shall not trouble you any longer. I am now become her Guardian.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: In good timeâ€” Well Mistress, I shall see you shortly live like those at the other end of the Town; you in one House, and your Husband in another: You with your Gallant, and he with his Mistress, as they call'emâ€” You could not be contented with a good, honest, civil Shop-keeper.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have done you no hurt I hope, to bestow the honest Shop-keeper you had provided for me upon your own Daughter.

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: Come mother, you shan't be angry hey, you shall get us a Sack Posset hey, and we will dance and be merry hey â€” Come awayâ€” let us go see my mad Father, heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I doubt this News will make him ten times madderâ€” Paul, shew me the way to your Master.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Sly, and Mrs. Sly.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Where is Brother Turbulent? we are come to see him in Tribulation, and to assist him with a word of Comfort.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sly.
sp.p: I fear Brother Turbulent is fallen away from his Principles, being seduced by his Nephew Furnish; and now he suffers for his Backsliding,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Are you freed from the Oppression of the Aegyptian Dragon Right-or-wrong. How got you forth of the paw of the Bear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: We were delivered.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: What Canting is this?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: This is the Language of the Saints.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: None of the Languages of Babel.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How came you reconciled?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sly.
sp.p: We have forgiven each other, least the wicked and Reprobate should reproach us for our Failings; and least we should become a Scandal, and a Stumbling Block to the Godly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Mr. Furnish is a vile, and an abominable man. Oh 'tis a wicked and unregenerate Age.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sly.
sp.p: Where Vice reigns triumphant, and runs down like a Streamâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let us be gone, they are falling again into their Old Fitsâ€” The Round-house has not cured 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I am going to see Tim.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: We will go with youâ€” my Bowels yearn, I am full of Compassion.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Polluxâ€”hast thou bespoke a Dinner over the way at the Popes Headâ€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: All things are ready for youâ€” and I have bespoke the Fiddlers: They will be here instantly, to play you to Dinnerâ€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And we'll have one mad frisk among the mad Folks.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I like that Fa la la laâ€” Exeunt.

div.stage: The Scene draws, and discovers Mr. Turbulent, Suckthumb, and Sneak sitting together.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: They are a company of Rogues, Varlets, Cheats, Trapanners, Villains, to make me mad, and to feed me with Bread and Porridgeâ€” These are Babylonian daysâ€” Oh the Oppression of Pharoah, and the Tyranny of Dyonisius.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Bear thy Tribulation with Patience, and be in the Meeknessâ€” We shall be delivered.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I have a Friend at Court that will soon release me; and I will inform of the Abuse.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I despise the Court, I hate the Court, 'tis a vile Abomination, and stinks of Prophaneness. Oh name not the Court, I cannot endure the sound of it in my Ears.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Thou speakest well, hold fast to thy Principles, and thou shalt be delivered from the paw of the Lion.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I begin to doubt these two are madâ€” But I am not yet convinc'd, but the Woman as bit me by the Ear was soberâ€” She did it, that they might not suspect our Plotâ€”'twas so.

div.stage: Enter Dr. Quibus and Lady Medler.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Here be de tree mad fokes, de several sorts of de melanchollicks; dey make de very good Harmony.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I am sorry to see you here Mr. Turbulent; but they say, there is no better place in the World to get Cureâ€” You have studied too hard I doubt Mr. Turbulent.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p:
Do you come to jeer and mock me too? Are you one of the Reprobates? Ay, ay, you glory and fawn on the Evil Timesâ€”
you are a a very unsanctified Hypocrite, that you areâ€” Pray be gone and meddle not with us.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Alas! poor man, I now see he is distracted.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I see you are an old medling Foolâ€”

sp.speaker: L. Med.
sp.p: Old Fool! Old Fool! Thou art a distracted Ass, a mad, hair-brain'd, raving Coxcomb. Old Foolâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Yes, thou art wrinkled in Iniquity, and grown hoary with Evil. Foh, thou smellest of the other end of the Town, and art combined against me.

sp.speaker: L. Med.
sp.p: He is raving, stark mad â€” 'Tis well he is here, I could not have believ'd it, had not my Eyes seen it, and my Ears heard his madness.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sneak,
sp.p: how is it with you?

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I was thinking of the Woman that bit me by the Ear â€” I tell you she is a great Heiress.

sp.speaker: L. Med.
sp.p: Well Mr. Sneak, I always took you to be a little craz'd; but now I find you are mad; and that nothing but good Diet and Physick will cure you.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Madam, de talk is very naught for de mad Folks; me vil give dem de Pill of de Ellebore; and you sall see in de tree, or de fore days, dey vil be very much amendedâ€”Let dem tink, let dem tink.

div.stage: Enter Fairlove, Friendly, Cringe, Pollux, Mrs. Turbulent, Priscilla, Keeper, Mr, Sly, and Mrs. Sly.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: Here are those you enquire for, I shall provide them Chambers apart: For madness, like other Diseases, is infectious; and they will hurt one anotherâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Tim.â€”How is it Tim.â€”Do'st thou know me Tim? thy own dear wife Tim.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I know you for a Harlot, a conspiring Harlot, a wicked she Devil, to bring me here to Bedlamâ€” But I'll tear thy Eyes outâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Alas! he is raving: Good Doctor Quibus, will you do your Endeavor. Do you think he will ever be his own man again?

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Do not fear: me vill give him de excellent Pill in de Varld: For de Cholerick melancholly; but he no eat de Caudle, nor de Turky Eggs; he no cram, cram, cram.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You are a Rogue, Doctor, and would starve me hereâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: He knows what is best for you Timâ€” but here is your Daughter Pris. and your Neece come, to see you: do you know 'em Timâ€” They have committed Matrimony, and provided for themselves.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Matrimony! Why, who are they are married to? â€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why Sir, you not being compos mentis, I have made bold to chuse me another Guardian, Mr. Fairlove hereâ€” I am his nowâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis well I am in Bedlamâ€”I find I am mad nowâ€” wicked, abominable Varletâ€”you shan't have a penny of Portion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have secur'd that already Sir, you know the Clause in the Willâ€”You are not compos mentis.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You are a cheating Harlotryâ€”I'll make you rue itâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have got only my own, which you would have cheated me ofâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: And who are you married to? To Pris.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Thy Rationallity is departedâ€”and thou canst not understand.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I an't asham'd to own my Priscilla heyâ€” I married her to spite Mrs. Lucyâ€” Shee agrees better with my Temper, heyâ€” We shall do well enough if she will like Verses, heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: O vile disobedient Wretch, marry a Poet, a maker of profane Verses, a Lover of Songs and tinkling Instruments, a wicked, abominable, wretched, vile, profane adultrousâ€”

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Holdâ€” stop his mouthâ€” he will lose his Breath elseâ€” This Poet, and maker of profane Verses, Uncle, you thought good enough for meâ€” why are you so angry? â€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Awayâ€”awayâ€” vile, abominable, conspiring Cheatsâ€” Instruments of Satanâ€” get you together, go, begon â€” the mad people are much better Company: You are full of Defilement, Sin, Pollution, and Abomination, away, begon.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: I am glad that in the midst of thy Madness, thou holdest fast to the Truth. Brother Turbulent, be comforted, and gird up thy Loyns, I hope thou wilt recover this delirious Fit; and that we shall again meet with a breathing forth, for the strengthening and edifyin one another.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Go, get you together, I say I am not mad; but you are all a company of Fools and Cheats: This Usage will cure me, and let me see my self.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Let us depart, Brother Turbulent is disturbed; I doubt the Fumes of the unsanctified Wine are not yet out of his Headâ€” Let him have rest.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Go, go, take your turn in Morefields, with your black Patches, and yellow Hood, the marks of the Beastâ€”

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Do not scandalize my Chickenâ€” I'll take the Law of you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Oh abominable, profane and reproachful mad manâ€” I'll leave thee and thy madness together.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: So â€” so â€” the Brethers and the Sisters are falling to pieces.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Well Tim. I hope to see thee restored again to thy right Sencesâ€” Dr. Quibus will take care of you.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Will you leave me here then?

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p:
Dis is de best place for you in de Varld Mr. Turbulent; here you may be turbulent, and rail at the Times, at de Government, at de Governors: Here you may speak de Treason all de
day long, vitout de danger of de Prison, or of de Punishment.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But Master, they will not feed you we â€¢ I doubt.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Rogue, Sirrah, Jack, Varlet, Raskal, Dev â€¢ l, do you prate? â€”

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What a many of Christian Names have I? Well Master, fare you well, I have provided my self of another Master here, Mr. Fairlove; but you first left me, and got a new Habitation.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Let me go to my own House I sayâ€” you will starve me hereâ€” you Doctor Devil.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Nay, dou shall have de Porridge in de Voden Dish; dou shall have de boil'd Mutton, and de Bred, and de Beer, and de Pill of de Ellebore now, tree times de Weekâ€”

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Father Turbulent, fare you well, hey â€” We will talk of your Daughter's Portion hereafter, heyâ€” Fa la la la laâ€”

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dis de great pity Monsieur Cringe is not in de Betlem tooâ€” He very mush vants de Cure: he is mush trobled in de head vit de fa laâ€”

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh let him alone, Doctor, he has got a worse Bedlam behalf: His new married Wife will soon cure his fa laâ€” you shall see

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dey be bote mad.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And will help to cure one anotherâ€”

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I will shut my Eyes against the Vanities of the Earth, and will stop my Ears, that I may not hear the abominable Noise of the musical Instruments: For this is a time of Tribulationâ€”

div.stage: Pulling his Hat over his Eyes, and stopping his Ears.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I will continue here willinglyâ€” I shall get the Opportunity of meeting with the Heiress that is in Love with meâ€” I shall get her, and that will be worth my Stayâ€” Let them see who is mad thenâ€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Oh I hear the Fiddles, they are coming â€” we will have one Dance among the mad Folks.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But first, shut up my Uncle, he will be stark mad indeed elseâ€”

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh the wicked, abominable, riotous Age, Oh the noysom Fiddles, the Provocatives to Lightness and Skipping together, like the Goats, frisking with their Tails of Wantonnessâ€”Fire Sword Plague, Pestilence, Riot, Luxury, Chambering, Hell, Confusion, Blood, Tempest, Storm, Thunder, Lightning, Hail and Hail-stones, fall on yourâ€”

div.stage: The Scene shuts in Turbulent, Suckthumb and Sneak.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Soâ€”soâ€”I thought the Noise of the Fiddles would make him stark madâ€”

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Let us be gone fro â€¢ the Carnal Noise of these lewd Instruments.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: We will â€¢ eturn to our Vocationâ€” Oh the abominable Wickedness of t â€¢â€¢ s riotous Age.

div.stage: Exeunt Mr. Sly, and Mrs. Sly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So, we are rid of our Anabaptists.

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: They would spoil our Sport, hey â€” they are not fit Company for us, heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Plainly, these are the Carnal Instruments of Vanity.

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: Don't speak against 'em, heyâ€” We will have a Dance, heyâ€” Come, come, come, and you shall dance too, heyâ€”

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: I will yield to thy Frailty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Where is my Cousin Furnish? We want him to make one here.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: 'Faith Madam, it has been a fatal Morning with Mr. Furnishâ€” He is under Tribulation.

sp.speaker: L. Med.
sp.p: Where is he? what ails he?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Alas poor man! Intending to come hither, a Brace of Sergeants, or Devils, which you will, snap'd him upon an Execution, and has carried him to the Coach and Horses in Woodstreet; From thence Madam, I am come to be his Solicitor to you, that you may redeem him this time, or he is utterly lost.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Let him go to the Devil if he will â€” he ows me too much alreadyâ€”

sp.speaker: Frien.
sp.p: 'Faith Madam, that's unkind, I will speak one good word for the Gentleman, though I'm a Stranger to him; because he is so necessary an Evil the Commonwealth cannot be without. If it were not for such as he, Fools having the Favor of Fortune, would not know what to do with their Money. 'Tis they get Riches, and such as he ease them of the Burthen. They do but dispend their money for them, and set it into motion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay Madam, help him this once, I'll joyn with youâ€” he shall never suffer on my Wedding day.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Well, tell him, he shall have the money sent him anonâ€” I'll make the Rogue pay me for'tâ€”

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Thank you Madamâ€”So, I think it was well he was arrestedâ€” He always comes off with flying Colorsâ€”

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: Come, you spoil our Sport, heyâ€” Leave your Whispers and your Business till another time, heyâ€” Fa la la laâ€” Come Fiddles, strike upâ€”

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come now, let us go over to the Pope's Head; you shall all be my Guests to day; and there Mr. Cringe shall have his Belly full of Dancing.

sp.speaker: Frin.
sp.p: I never was at a Wedding in Bedlam before.

sp.speaker: Fair.

p.hi: Fanaticks here may safely have their Frollicks.

sp.p: The World's Great Bethlem, most men Melanchollicks.
